Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XPM-N3T1-F11P-X1K0-00000-00Future of Banking: Six Commandments of Digital Banking in 20202019-12-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:51ZLexisNexisFuture of Banking: Six Commandments of Digital Banking in 2020

"In the future, we anticipate seeing more joint ventures, acquisitions, and investments in Fintech firms. Incumbent banks can learn from and acquire Fintechs to enhance existing offerings, provide new services, address customer needs and improve operational efficiency. All financial institutions will need to evolve – incumbents, digital banks and neo banks." ……… Acxiom

Nobody will disagree that the banking industry is going through massive changes unlike anything seen in decades. New technologies are impacting legacy banking models and consumer expectations, as well as the competitors in the marketplace. We are even seeing changes in the way financial institutions engage with consumers across their financial lifecycle. The question is, what are the most important trends that we will need to take action on in the next 12-18 months? More importantly, what action is needed? As banking grows more complex, it is becoming more difficult to deliver seamless customer experiences and consistency across channels. Banks are responding by using advanced digital technologies and new business models to build better customer experiences.

Transformation in banking will continue beyond 2020, but building competencies that can take advantage of these trends needs to begin now. Here are six (6) of the most important trends that can be expected in 2020 as outlined by Jim Marous and the Financial Brand in a research:

The battle between Cyberthreats and Cybersecurity

Organizations and the public at large are increasingly aware of the threat of cybercrimes and the importance of cybersecurity. That said, most organizations are struggling to keep up with the risk of cyberthreats. From data breaches and IT security staff shortages to security automation and integration cybersecurity will remain a top technology trend in banking. Ensuring data privacy, and the security of personal data, continues to be a challenge as data breaches continue daily.

The challenge is exacerbated because of the cybersecurity skills gap. In fact, as many as two in three organizations worldwide reported a shortage of IT security staff. While automation of some functions can relieve some of the pressure, web applications combining multiple web services are increasingly hard to secure. On top of the traditional threats, the increase in mobile devices, internet of things (IoT) devices and the continued threat of state-sponsored attacks only adds to the challenge.

An Age of Collaboration

With change in the banking industry happening so quickly, it is impossible for any organization, of any size to "go it alone." The value of establishing the right strategic partnerships has never been greater. "Partnering can extend products and platforms into new markets, expose brands to new customer segments and create scale," Acxiom observes. The ultimate objective is to improve the customer experience with an enhanced value transfer. When the right strategic partners are selected, there should be greater agility, a seamless integration with systems and products already in place, and a synergy not possible previously. There also needs to be a flexibility within the partnership that will allow the collaboration to adjust to marketplace changes without needing to renegotiate the relationship.

Going forward, partnerships will extend beyond traditional providers to include fintech firms, big tech organizations, communities and potentially even governmental units. In some instances, solution providers will partner with each other to enable a better integration within banks and credit unions with less internal and external friction.

Done well, these bilateral and multilateral networks of providers will be able to deliver more personalized solutions than was possible previously. Imagine 8-10 different savings or lending solutions being available for different segments the retail consumer or business population. These solutions will increase engagement as well as value to the consumer (and financial institution). This will be accomplished by leveraging new data assets, advanced analytics, and modern communication platforms.

An Age of Enhanced Data Utilization

With enhanced sources of data and technology to process insights, there is an unparalleled opportunity to proactively identify consumer needs and the appropriate product or service to be offered. Beyond using a simple demographic, product ownership and risk-based profile, banks can deliver greatly improved results by combining both traditional and non-traditional data.

Today, financial marketers and product managers have access to lifestyle and psychographic data, financial and non-financial product ownership and purchase data, channel preference insights, brand loyalties, geo-location data and even insights from social media use. These enhanced insights, when combined with advanced analytics will not only provide purchase propensity information, but also the projected timing of need.

The result is highly personalized communication that the consumer will welcome delivered to the device or platform the consumer prefers. Done well, this also can increase the prospect market beyond what was possible before, reaching previously underserved consumers who may only have a "thin file" with less data available.

An Age of the Non-Traditional Player

What legacy financial institutions have in capital, customers and infrastructure, they often lack in speed, innovation and a genuine focus on the consumer. This is why more and more fintech firms have not only entered the banking ecosystem, but have succeeded in moving market share. The payments ecosystem will never be the same, and the lending battlefield is getting more and more crowded with new players filling the needs of an increasingly diverse consumer.

Fintech firms compete by serving the consumer without being tied to a legacy of operations and organizational rules and structure. This allows them to provide products and services that are faster, easier, and/or cheaper than what traditional banks can deliver. According to Acxiom, "The movement toward open banking and open APIs will only increase the speed of change as fintech business models and technologies allow them to align with new opportunities very quickly." The consumer wants speed, simplicity, intuitive design and the ability to complete a task with a simple push of a button. Legacy financial institutions struggle to provide that level of user experience. Beyond smaller fintech organizations, big tech firms are now leveraging their platforms to combine shopping, ride-sharing, searching and engaging with new distribution options for traditional financial services.

While there has always been the benefit of trust on the side of legacy financial institutions, big tech firms as well as smaller fintech firms that have been in existence for more than a few years are receiving trust scores approaching and even surpassing legacy banks and credit unions. This should be a cause for concern especially for mid-tier and smaller financial institutions in the foreseeable future.

An Age of Advanced Marketing Performance

Data, advanced analytics and the deployment of new marketing technologies make it possible to target and specific audience at the proper time of engagement better than ever in the past. And, at a time when fewer consumers are switching providers, effective multichannel marketing is needed to stimulate new customer and organic growth.

The challenge is that the ability to measure the effectiveness of increasing investments in marketing has lagged. With most organizations using multichannel marketing campaigns, it is more important than ever to measure the effectiveness of each channel in the customer journey and to understand the best cadence and sequence of messages for the optimal ROI.

In the end, last-touch attribution is no longer an acceptable measure. Instead, it is imperative to understand the interrelationships of channels and messages to apply spending to the key moments of a customer purchase journey

An Age of the Platform Economy

"A platform is a plug-and-play business model that allows multiple participants (producers and consumers) to connect to it, interact with each other and create and exchange value," according to Acxiom, While the retail industry has the greatest number of organizations with platforms (50), the financial services industry has 26 platforms organizations, according to a KPMG analysis.

A true platform would offer products and services from multiple organizations to serve the needs of a broader array of consumers. Most financial institutions have not come close to offering a platform solution. This could definitely be a problem in the future.

As we approach 2020, it is clear that we can't stop change or the impact it is having on banking, the consumer and even regulators. Today's consumer expectation is different from the past, and they will continue to change in the future. As consumer expectations change, so must the financial institutions that serve them. If traditional organizations don't meet the needs, fintech or big tech firms will.

Notes:

urn:contentItem:5T0S-XY71-F0JP-W38W-00000-00Future of finance: open warfare and, gulp, Amazon2018-08-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:52ZLexisNexisWEALTHPg. 33Future of finance: open warfare and, gulp, AmazonAlan Kohler

After what Australia's big four banks have been getting up to, and the pitiless way that has been exposed this year, open banking is going to be a complete disaster for them.

The new regime starts next July and will lay the banks bare to competition. They will be tethered goats in a clearing. The final report of the banking royal commission will still be hanging in the air like the scent of fear, along with the (Labor?) government's response to it.

Not that the final report could be much worse than what's coming out now, you'd think, including this headline in The Australian on Wednesday: "NAB charged dead customers".

Dear, oh dear. Was that the low water mark? They hope.

This week, hapless NAB executives were cooked on the royal commission rotisserie over a fire of $34 million in fees that had to be given back to 220,000 customers because nothing had been done for the money. Some of those customers had shuffled off this mortal coil and ceased to be in need of NAB's services. CBA had been doing the same thing, as well as helping mobsters with their money-laundering problems. NAB had misled ASIC as well. So had AMP.

And we learnt this week from CBA's annual report that its executives had lost some $100 million in bonuses. A hundred million bucks? You mean they would have got that much if they hadn't been bad?

So next year, the banks will have to start handing over customers' data and making it available to competitors, on request, including through application program inter-faces (APIs) that will make it super easy for those customers to be spirited away. APIs will allow competitors to offer specific, narrow banking services and cherry-pick the most profitable bits of the banks.

Who will take advantage of the "open banking" regime and compete with them? For an answer, I spoke to David Duffy, CEO of CYBG, the British bank that is dual listed on the ASX and the London Stock Exchange, having been hived out of NAB two years ago (the C stands for Clydesdale and the Y for Yorkshire, the two prongs of NAB's ill-fated attempt to bestow its vast banking expertise on the rest of the world).

Britain has had open banking for a few months, and Duffy's sixth-ranked bank is now using it to vigorously attack the five above him. As part of that, CYBG is in the process of buying Virgin Money to be used as the brand for its digital bank.

But he said that most of all, the British banks, including his own, are preparing for a siege against new competitors, from outside their ranks.

Who from? Amazon, that's who.

Duffy told me: "What I'm -focused on is the Amazons of the world who are talking to banks and talking to regulators about becoming part of the banking system in some way.

"They've yet to make that a very specific move, but the dialogue between an Amazon or an equivalent large tech firm is very significant and I think what you're looking at is a big tech entrance to the marketplace over time and that could have dramatic consequences in terms of the infrastructure activity of banks versus the cost to provide the same by those tech firms." Duffy believes open banking in Britain and Europe is producing an inflection point for the industry.

"I think what you should be looking at in terms of an inflection point is the combination of an open banking environment and the threat of large tech companies, disintermediating banking services, either in the payments industry aspect of the banks or in other parts of the service model or in parts of the scaled infrastructure. Those forces coming together over the next five years is where I think you're seeing a fundamental shift in how banking is provided to the customer versus the past." In Australia, of course, there is another force of nature, in the person of royal commissioner Ken Hayne, and the orgy of customer neglect, and worse, that he has brought forth.

The combination of open banking in Australia and the royal commission is one of those freakish coincidences that defines history.

The process of bringing -Europe-style open banking to this country was kicked off by Scott Morrison on July 20 last year when he commissioned an Open Banking Review from a panel chaired by Scott Farrell, a partner of law firm King & Wood -Mallesons.

Ironically, it was part of the Treasurer's defence against the ALP's calls for banking royal commission: the Turnbull government, he said, was reforming the system and doing the things that would come of a royal commission anyway. But that was before CBA was done for thousands of breaches of money laundering laws, which was the final straw.

Morrison and -Malcolm Turnbull threw in the towel on November 20 and announced a royal commission.

Scott Farrell, meanwhile, produced his report in December.

There followed a period of consultation and no one with whom he consulted thought it was a bad idea, although the response of the banks and the Australian Banking Association could best be characterised as: "Yes, but".

In fact, the ABA submission might have been written by Antony Jay and Jonathan Lynn, the writers of Yes Minister of blessed memory (Jay died in 2016; Lynn is 75 and lives in Bath).

Morrison produced his response to the Farrell Review on May 9 this year and it didn't get a lot of attention, coming, as it did, during one of the royal commission's public hearing hunting seasons.

The April hearings into -financial advice had been spectacular, and everybody was still reeling.

Cornered, Morrison revealed a 12-month phase-in period, saying: "Open Banking will also allow entrepreneurs to develop new services and products tailored to customers' needs, disrupting those existing business models within the banking sector that do not put customers first." That would be all of them, I -believe.Alan Kohler is publisher of The Constant Investor.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VFG-GHJ1-DYTY-C4SN-00000-00Future of journalism in spotlight2019-02-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:51ZLexisNexisBUSINESS;NEWSPg. 7Future of journalism in spotlightST E V E D EMP S E Y

LAST year the UK Government commissioned a report on safeguarding the future of journalism. This task was given to Dame Frances Cairncross, below, a former editor for The Economist and columnist for The Guardian. This week she produced her report. It featured some sensible recommendations.

"We are likely to see a further decline in the size of the UK's news publishing sector - in journalists and in titles," she said. "Ultimately, the biggest challenge facing the sustainability of high-quality journalism and the press may be the same as that which is affecting every area of life: the digital revolution means that people have more claims on their attention than ever before.

Moreover, the stories people want to read may not always be the ones that they ought to read in order to ensure that a democracy can hold its public servants properly to account." So what suggestions did she have to offer? Some related to financial supports like lowering Vat on digital news subscriptions to bring online paywalls into line with printed newspapers, tax relief for publishers that invest in public interest journalism, and even potentially giving charitable status to some publishers. The report also recommends the creation of a fund focused on innovations to improve the supply of public-interest news and a new Institute for Public Interest News, which would distribute funding and work with publishers on sustainable public-interest news.

Then there's big tech. Dame Cairncross calls for the UK competition regulator to investigate whether the dominance of Facebook and Google is detrimental to public interest news sources.

She also favours a new regulated code of conduct between publishers and large tech companies. But the report doesn't make the tech industry out to be the bad guys. Cairncross rejects any suggestion that Facebook and Google should be made to pay publishers to host news content, warning that this could limit the spread of news to those who want to see it.

Publishers catch some of the flak for their own downfall in the Cairncross Review. It points out that many newspaper groups in the UK have failed to invest in the infrastructure and innovations needed to forge a successful digital future, instead they've focused on making cuts or restructuring their debt.

The UK isn't the only country where such an interrogation of the issues facing the news industry has taken place. In the US the Knight Commission on Trust, Media, and Democracy recently issued a hefty 200-plus page report. It's not government backed, and as a result lacks the policy-punch that the Cairncross review delivers. But it does cover many similar bases - how to restore trust in journalism and revitalise publishing.

The overarching recommendation is that news organisations need to be radically transparent and interwoven with the communities they cover. This means prioritising reporting and evidence-based commentary over opinion, implementing best practices around corrections and fact-checking, and engaging with communities to improve the relevance of reporting and increase trust.

The Knight Commission report homes in on the growth of non-profit news outlets. "As profit-driven newspapers continue their economic decline, the Commission recommends accelerated investment in non-profit, mission-driven journalistic entities we call Community News Organisations", it says.

Like the Cairncross review, the Knight Commission report also has a section on technology. News companies need to embrace technology to support their mission and achieve sustainability it says. And it rightly points out that there is an inequality of resources in relation to news organisations and technology.

The New York Times and the Washington Post can afford data journalists, AI experts, engineers and app developers, but many local news entities struggle to keep the lights on.

Given the travails of the news industry in the developed world, the growth of the internet as a advertising powerhouse and as a vector for the spread of misinformation, plus the threatened extinction of local media outlets, it's vital that the points raised by the likes of the Cairncross Review and the Knight Commission are discussed by policymakers and civil society. The news media itself can't be a passenger, here. It must engage with the valid criticisms in such research and do better than waiting for government handouts, because Facebook and Google came along and threatened its business model.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RXP-XC01-DYWP-R2J6-00000-00Future of TV in balance as AT&T, Time Warner plead merger case2018-03-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:51ZLexisNexisBUSINESSFuture of TV in balance as AT&T, Time Warner plead merger case

WASHINGTON: Fans will be glued to the "March Madness" college basketball tournament as the joint owner of rights for the games, Time Warner Inc , goes before a judge on Thursday to defend a proposed takeover by AT&T Inc . With some 12 million viewers per game last year, the NCAA tournament exemplifies the marquee programming the U.S. government argues will become more expensive if Time Warner is bought by AT&T, the biggest pay-TV provider via subsidiary DirecTV. The Justice Department filed a lawsuit in November to stop AT&T, which has some 25 million pay-TV subscribers, from closing the US$85 billion deal. AT&T says a merger benefits consumers by creating efficiencies. If the government loses, that could open up the field for similar tie-ups between distributors and content providers.

But a win could strengthen the hand of antitrust regulators looking at other, similarly structured mergers. Opening arguments in the case are set for Thursday before Judge Richard Leon in Washington, who will decide the case. They were delayed one day by bad weather. The merger would hand AT&T, if it becomes the new owner of Time Warner, the motive and opportunity to refuse to license the March Madness games, along with premium cable channel HBO and other content, to pay-TV rivals and online distributors, the Justice Department says. The case is unusual for several reasons. To begin with, President Donald Trump criticized the proposed deal during his campaign and since taking office. AT&T lawyer Daniel Petrocelli had asked for access to communications between the White House and Justice Department about the deal, but Judge Leon denied the request. AT&T and Time Warner also are not direct competitors, making the deal a so-called vertical merger between companies on the same supply chain. The vast majority of challenged mergers involve one rival buying another. If the government loses, Verizon Communications Inc and Charter Communications Inc could strike deals to buy movie or television makers and squeeze smaller pay-TV providers. "I don't know if anyone is big enough to swallow up Netflix but you know they want to," said Gene Kimmelman, president of the advocacy group Public Knowledge. AT&T has said the merger would result in more than US$2.5 billion in annual cost savings by 2020. It also plans to argue the deal is crucial to compete with companies like Facebook Inc , Alphabet Inc , Amazon.com Inc and Netflix Inc . The internet companies pose two challenges to pay TV. They either compete with cable and satellite television for ad dollars or provide cheaper online video that has hurt pricey pay-TV. Some do both. Consumers could be hurt if AT&T is reluctant to sell Time Warner content to online distributors in order to protect pay-TV at a time of declining subscriptions, Kimmelman said. "While everyone is very worried about the big tech giants for good reason, this isn t one of the concerns that makes any sense," he said, adding that he welcomed moves by Google and Amazon into video. Apple, Facebook and other vertically integrated tech companies are more powerful than media companies were 50 years ago because they own consumer data they can use to target advertising and predict future purchases, said Andrea Murino, an antitrust lawyer with Goodwin Procter LLP. This, combined with antitrust enforcers' preference for asset sales to resolve competitive concerns, could mean that more vertical deals will be challenged in court, she said. (Reporting by Diane Bartz in Washington, additional reporting by Jessica Toonkel in New York; Editing by Meredith Mazzilli) - Reuters

urn:contentItem:5X4N-5CD1-DXH2-651T-00000-00Futures Pointing Up; Whistleblower Statement to be Released; Trump Sounds off on Trade; Peloton's IPO Today; Investors Shrug off Impeachment Worries2019-09-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:51ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTSteve Forbes, Veronica Dagher, Lara Rhame, Robert Ray, Michael PrindivilleNEWSInternational092601cb.231Futures Pointing Up; Whistleblower Statement to be Released; Trump Sounds off on Trade; Peloton's IPO Today; Investors Shrug off Impeachment WorriesMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: With China. That certainly boosted markets yesterday. Futures are extending yesterday's gains with a gain this morning of 45 points on the Dow Industrials. S&P up four and the Nasdaq up five.

Peloton peddles its way forward, pricing its IPO at $29 a share. The high end of the price range despite still not bringing in a profit. What to expect when trading begins today from Peloton.

Plus, more trouble for Facebook this morning. Reports of another anti-trust investigation of the technology company, this time from the Justice Department. We've got the very latest.

MORNINGS WITH MARIA begins right now.

All right, we've got a big show this morning. Joining the conversation, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, back in her seat, "Wall Street Journal" wealth manager reporter, host of "The Secrets of Wealthy Women" podcast, Veronica Dagher is here, and Forbes Media chairman, former Republican presidential candidate, Steve Forbes.

Great to see everybody this morning.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Good to be with you.

VERONICA DAGHER, PODCAST HOST, "SECRETS OF WEALTHY WOMEN": Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we have a lot to talk about.

Dagen, missed you. A lot --

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: Missed you.

BARTIROMO: Wanted to get your take on all of these developments this morning.

Now we've got the whistleblower complaint that we are going to see declassified.

MCDOWELL: Right, with the acting director of national intelligence testifying in front of Congress later this morning, declassified last night.

Again, let the American people see it in, please, rather than having to listen to Adam Schiff and Chuck Schumer tell us what's in it and how disturbed they are by it.

I'll leave it at this. Are they -- the Democrats really going to try and impeach a president during an election year? That's why we have elections.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And -- and, again, I wonder if the -- the intent of all of this is to essentially destroy the economy and prevent everything from getting done that would benefit the American people, like the Canada-Mexico trade agreement, like, again, getting in the way of President Trump's negotiations with China.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: I just raised that question. I don't have answers.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: But it does -- it just looks like they're trying to -- not maybe do -- not maybe even impeach him, but just destroy the economy because of it.

BARTIROMO: Well, let's just stop --

MCDOWELL: Because of the uncertainty they foment.

BARTIROMO: Let's stop everything from moving forward.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: Right. I mean so -- so that's the -- that's what the markets focus on this story, the fact that there's no USMCA, there's no immigration, there's no health care, there's no infrastructure, nothing gets done legislatively. And it's just amazing to me that they could stand there and pursue these moves when, in fact, at the end, I think markets, investors, voters are going to blame them for that, Steve Forbes. What do you say?

FORBES: Well, it's going to be a thin excuse when you have six or eight congressional committees getting involved in this thing. But what they should do, if they were serious about it, was to have one select committee, or the Judiciary Committee, instead of every chairman and chairperson, chairwoman getting involved in this thing. So the Republicans should take up the gauntlet and challenge them every step of a way, have a formal vote on whether there's -- this thing should go forward, have them all go on record about it, have them state what they think has gone wrong.

If you could -- if you can take a call like that and impeach a president in an election year, by golly, everyone -- every president is vulnerable at every single moment.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FORBES: It's preposterous.

BARTIROMO: Not only that, but are we opening a precedent that any, you know, private phone call with the president is going to be made public because his skeptics or the adversaries want --

FORBES: Well, the only -- the only reason the president even did this was to try to show how ridiculous --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FORBES: And how, once again, they're playing Russian collusion games. It's the only reason he did it. But he should make clear, and I think he is trying to make clear, this is not a precedent, this is just trying to quash another one of these crazy investigations in its cradle rather than letting it consume them.

BARTIROMO: Somebody needs to stop, needs to say, this has got to stop.

First two and a half years to have Russia collusion, based on nothing but a dossier that was paid for by the Clinton campaign, now this, pursuing something that the whistleblower doesn't even have direct knowledge of in terms of this --

FORBES: Hearsay. Hearsay.

BARTIROMO: It's all hearsay.

MCDOWELL: Oh, by the way, "The New York Post" page six is reporting exclusively today that Nancy Pelosi, at a VIP dinner here in New York City at the St. Regis, on a Monday night, was dropping hints about impeachment. Monday night. So the --

BARTIROMO: They hadn't seen anything yet.

MCDOWELL: So, again, the memorandum of this conversation was released, what it, about 10:00 a.m. yesterday. OK.

BARTIROMO: Right.

MCDOWELL: So, again, that's been -- this has been the -- this has been the plan. And I'll get into the details of this "New York Post" report as the morning moves on.

But, again, this is what they've been planning all along. And when the Mueller report comes out and says no conspiracy, no collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia, that -- they ended up falling on their faces with that. So I -- it looks like they've been doing for anything to take down the president, who they -- they despise him.

BARTIROMO: Absolutely. They can't stop him.

FORBES: What it shows -- what it shows -- yes.

BARTIROMO: They just think -- and why do they despise him? My view, I said this yesterday, they despise him because Donald Trump's presence threatens their existence and they're so obsessed with holding onto their power. He came to Washington. He starts calling everybody out. The swamp this the swamp that. He starts forcing accountability for some of these jobs that people were in for years and did nothing for the American people. And so his presence there threatens their continued power.

MCDOWELL: Well, and I'll leave -- outside of the left-wing liberal media bubbles of New York, Washington, and the left coast, L.A. and San Francisco, individuals like in -- back where I grew up, all they're asking is, ah, Joe Biden's son was getting paid $50,000 a month --

BARTIROMO: That's right.

MCDOWELL: By a company in Ukraine for what?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Back in the day, that was called influence peddling.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: I'll leave --

BARTIROMO: This -- this in total -- this total exercise is going to blow Joe Biden out of the water, and that's what most people are expecting because --

DAGHER: And a lot of independent voters also aren't interested in this impeachment issue.

BARTIROMO: That's what Dagen's saying, yes.

DAGHER: It's not a focus for them.

MCDOWELL: It hasn't -- since the Mueller report came out in the spring, I think it was April -- mid-April, that the polling on impeachment -- and granted that was based on the Mueller report -- has been right around, I think, 35 percent to 37 percent. So a little bit more than a third of voters polled have -- have said that they're in favor of impeachment, but that hasn't moved. So, again, when that wasn't working, you move on to something else.

FORBES: But it also shows the -- how -- how powerful the fringe on the Democratic left is, Pelosi caved to them and she -- the whole party is now marching to their orders.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FORBES: And it's not going to help them in 2020.

BARTIROMO: Like the Republicans have been saying, AOC is the face of the Democratic Party. And she's co-speaker.

FORBES: She's -- she's the defacto -- she's the defacto speaker.

BARTIROMO: She's the defacto speaker, exactly.

OK, we want to continue this conversation throughout the show. We also want to tell you what the president said yesterday about trade. He commented on the impeachment inquiries impact on the USMCA trade deal and the prospects of an agreement with China.

Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Right now China is way behind us and they'll never catch us if we have smart leadership. Way behind. We've picked up trillions of dollars and they've lost trillions of dollars. And they want to make a deal very badly. It could happen. Could happen.

(CROSS TALK)

TRUMP: It could happen.

(CROSS TALK)

TRUMP: It could happen sooner than you think.

I don't think Nancy Pelosi will have time. She's wasting her time on a -- you know, let's use a word that they used to use a lot, a manufactured crisis.

It's phenomenal for farmers. It's good for manufacturers. It's good for everybody. Even the unions want it because they've always hated NAFTA. The unions want it.

I don't know that they're ever going to get to a vote because they're all fight, the Democrats are all fighting with themselves. So, we'll see. If it happens, it happens, otherwise when we take over the House next year, we'll do it our way.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And that's what some Wall Street reporters yesterday, Wall Street research, were saying that this may very well lead to the House flipping in 2020.

And, Veronica, do you see a chance of USMCA or a China deal happening?

DAGHER: You know what, it sounds like it could be less likely now, right, because if the Congress is so tied up with this impeachment inquiry, then things don't get done.

And, you know, we had a report yesterday just talking about how much our farmers need a deal done. They are suffering. They're having financial difficulties. This is an ongoing story and they are looking to Washington to get something done sooner than later. They have some financial protection for their businesses, but this cannot go on forever for our farmers.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And over the near term they actually have to fund the government.

DAGHER: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: There's -- there's that as well in the next couple of days.

FORBES: Well, one of the things that actually may come out of this whole impeachment nonsense is that Pelosi now has the cover to bring USMCA to a vote and not be accused by the left of selling out to Trump and providing some cover for her moderate members. She knows she's got 20 to 30 members who come from districts that can swing very easily. She's not worried about so much AOC, she's worried about those 20 or 30. She's got to give them something to go back and say to the voters, hey, we got something done.

BARTIROMO: Yes, but, I mean, can you see that happening in the face of all this? Ronna McDaniel, Romney, yesterday sat where you're sitting and she said, we're going right for those Trump, you know, areas where actually they were flipped and a Democrat is there. We're going to go right for them in 2020 and we are going to make this what they're doing in terms of impeachment work for us.

FORBES: Yes. And that's what Pelosi is word about. She caved to the left. She felt she had to. She lost control of her caucus. So she's got to come up with something that they can go back to their districts and say, hey, for all the headlines, we got something done for you.

MCDOWELL: And it only takes 18. The Republicans only need 18 seats to flip it back -- flip the House back to red.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And, you know, even though you've seen retirements, I think they are more unified today than they ever have.

MCDOWELL: They're -- I think there are 18 Republican retirements. I think. But 18 is the -- the kind of -- I think it's the round number with the Republican victory in North Carolina recently in the special election.

FORBES: Two of them.

MCDOWELL: Yes, exactly.

BARTIROMO: All right, we've got a couple of other pieces of business this morning. IPOs continue strongly. Peloton is going public today. The company pricing its IPO at $29 a share. That is the higher end of the range. For -- this -- this company keeps innovating. We'll see. I mean you're still looking at a no-profit, but you are seeing a growth story within Peloton, I think.

Reaction?

MCDOWELL: It is the recurrent revenue stream that they built into these machines. Again, it's not about the device, it's about the -- you get hooked on it and you continue to pay month after month after month.

But, again, with the WeWork disaster, this company looks pretty good.

BARTIROMO: Yes. That's right.

DAGHER: And the subscription model is popular, as you mentioned.

What's interesting, though, their competitor, Soul Cycle, hasn't yet to become public, right? They keep delaying. There's some talk, when is this going to happen? So you wonder if there's something fundamentally about the business model that makes it difficult for these companies to succeed (INAUDIBLE).

MCDOWELL: I don't think Soul Cycle's that much of a competitor, because this is, I hate people and I'd rather exercise alone where I don't have to wear makeup and I can sweat just like Richard Nixon.

DAGHER: Fair point.

BARTIROMO: It's actually a really good (INAUDIBLE).

FORBES: (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: I have -- I have a Peloton. It's really a really nice bike.

DAGHER: I do have one.

FORBES: It's amazing, self-torture machines and you get rich.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And they have -- and they have treadmills too. Very expensive (INAUDIBLE).

DAGHER: (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: And then they've got that new thing where it's a mirror. You're in the mirror and you can have a whole yoga class behind you.

DAGHER: That's really cool.

BARTIROMO: You know, that's what I'm saying, they keep -- they keep innovating.

DAGHER: Surprise (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: But continued commentary about the private market being overvalued, some of these valuations within the private sector are excessive. We heard that from a lot of people recently. Larry Ellison, Steve Schwarzman, on this program.

So we'll be watching the pricing here and how it goes public this morning.

We are just getting started this morning.

Also on deck, New Meta Entertainment CEO Michael Prindiville is here on the big business of gaming. And that is one of the most successful areas of entertainment. Pennsylvania Congressman, House Foreign Affairs Committee member Scott Perry is here on the Iran sanctions. And the Caliber Home Loan CEO Sanjiv Das on lower mortgage rates. Plus, the secretary of NATO, Secretary-general Jens Stoltenberg on his meeting with the Ukraine president and, of course, the week that is and is continuing at the U.N. this week.

A big show this morning. Please join us coming up.

But first, Hong Kong's future. Leader Carrie Lam is ready to meet with the community in an effort to restore the ongoing political chaos in the city, as millions continue to take to the streets, trying to push back on China's authoritarian rule.

Then Facebook is in the hot seat again. Attorney General William Barr readying a new anti-trust investigation into the social media giant. We're taking a look at that when we come right back.

Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

The leader of Hong Kong, Carrie Lam, trying to end the ongoing protests by reaching out to the community now.

Cheryl Casone with the details in headlines.

Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: That's right, Maria, good morning.

Carrie Lam out with an op-ed in "The New York Times." It's title, yes, Hong Kong does have a future. In the op-ed she says that she is listening, and that conversation can triumph over conflict. Lam is taking the conversation to the people, holding her first talks with the public today in an attempt to resolve a political crisis that has fueled nearly four months of protest and plunged the Chinese run city into chaos. Lam is going to hold a dialogue with 150 members of a community with each participant given around three minutes to express their views.

Well, We Work could get a big money boost. "The Financial Times" is reporting that Softbank is planning to pump an extra $1 billion, maybe more, into WeWork by renegotiating a warrant deal struck before falling valuations delayed the company's IPO. The plan would increase the Japanese firm's initially planned investment of $1.5 billion in WeWork. WeWork has seen a leadership shake-up and big plans for job cuts in their effort to go public. Again, that is delayed.

And Walmart is getting into the health care business through its Sam's Club stores. Starting next month, Sam's Club members in Michigan, Pennsylvania and North Carolina are going to be able to buy one of four bundles of health care services. They range in price from $50 for individuals to $240 for families. That would be per year. The pilot program could eventually be rolled out to members in every state. Under the program, patients will be diagnosed and treated. Patients without -- that don't want to talk to or even see a doctor can do that as well. Virtual care, right? Patients use an app to describe symptoms to an automated assistant. That uses, of course, AI, Maria. The information gets passed on along to a doctor. Health care, again, going digital, whether it's Skype, or on the phone, or, you know, texting, it's just changing the way that we see our doctors or actually do not see the doctor.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it really is and it's important. It's going to be one of the big industries that gets impacted in a good way from technology now.

Thank you, Cheryl.

MCDOWELL: And this -- this comes as -- from the Kaiser Family Foundation report, the cost of employee-provided health coverage topped $20,000 a year for the very first time. The families are paying -- find that the premiums rose 5 percent for family plans. It's the cost of buying an economy car every year.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

MCDOWELL: That's so -- again, that's the pressure on not just private businesses, but also politicians to bring those costs down.

BARTIROMO: All right, we'll talk a break.

When we come back, General Motor workers are still on strike. The automaker and the union may be closer to a deal this morning. We've got the very latest there as buyers and dealers are really starting to feel the effects of this standoff.

And then Alexa's iconic upgrade. A Hollywood star lending his unmistakable voice to Amazon's home assistant. Find out who when we come back.

Plus, a stock alert. Beyond Meat shares are soaring this morning after McDonald's says it plans to test a new meatless burger in Canada. Beyond Meat is up almost 10 percent.

Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Well, markets have been watching with one eye the impeachment inquiry developments, the deals, of course, on trade, more important there for the market's impact. Yesterday the markets finished higher after the White House released a read-out of the president's July phone call with the Ukrainian president. President Trump was optimistic also about China trade yesterday.

Joining us right now is FS Investment's chief U.S. economist Lara Rhame.

And, Lara, it's good to see you again. Thanks so much for joining us.

LARA RHAME, CHIEF U.S. ECONOMIST, FS INVESTMENTS: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Characterize the economy for us right now.

RHAME: So relatively solid but lopsided. We're seeing a solid consumer, strong consumer even, but that uneven impact from trade is hitting manufacturing. The concern is whether the sort of rising uncertainty coming at us from different directions is going to spread. It's going to -- the tentacles are going to spread out and impact that consumer.

BARTIROMO: So any -- any impacts from this impeachment inquiry from your standpoint? What do the last two days mean to markets and investing?

RHAME: So, you know, markets seemed to have absorbed this fairly well, which is really good news. You know, we had recent data out for the household showing that wealth is higher but it's largely because of equity market gains. When the consumer is overly exposed to the equity market, we start to worry about things like volatility. So the fact that markets are taking it well so far is good.

FORBES: When -- when is the slowdown in investment, you know, capital expenditures start to hit the consumer side? You have to produce to consume. And do you see any signs of a turnaround there or it's just the uncertainty is going to keep it lower than it should be.

BARTIROMO: And -- and just let me point out that Vice President Pence, yesterday, when I interviewed him a couple of days ago said CapEx is turning around again. I don't know how you feel about that, but I know a month ago we were talking about CapEx being down. He was adamant in saying, no, no, no, no, look at the most recent reading. It's actually turning again.

What do you say?

RHAME: Yes, so I think it's all -- it is a little bit slower, but part of that is just due to the global slowdown. It's when we get slower growth in Germany, when you get slower growth in these other big centers, it's going to naturally -- it's hard to fight gravity in the situation.

I think what we see in our company is very reticent to lay off workers and that is sort of the other side of CapEx spending. To me, if companies are willing to be a little more cautious on the CapEx spending but keep the workers, for our economy overall that's a really good thing.

DAGHER: What causes this consumer to fall out of bed?

RHAME: You know to -- I'm really looking hard at two things, whether or not we start to see the layoff increase. We're getting initial claims this morning. It's a little weekly indicator, but it's actually one of my favorites as a leading indicator for recession. So if we start to see the layoff tick up and they've stayed really low, which is one of the reasons why I'm not buying this recession concern as much.

BARTIROMO: We get GDP today too.

RHAME: Yes. It's a second quarter -- it's a revision, yes, but absolutely. And I think, you know, now we start to do the math on the third quarter, how that looks. It might be a little bit slower. But, you know, to me it's all about the jobs at that point.

FORBES: Well, let's be happy for a moment. Let's say there is a China deal. Do you see a spurt in investments as people now know the rules of the road?

RHAME: I think so. I mean clearly any resolution would be a positive. And markets are reacting very positively. We've seen that day by day for the last year on news on trade.

I think the concern to me is, you know, we've raised -- this administration has raised the really tough issues with China when you pull that thread, it's hard to knit the sweater back together again. When I -- when I see -- when I see a trade deal, the construct of a trade deal to me would still be one where there's heighten tensions about things like technology, data sharing, cyber security.

FORBES: Now we're still only -- still -- still only September. When -- when does the market start to react to the prospect -- possible prospect, let's pretend for a moment, Elizabeth Warren gets the Democratic nomination, when do the markets say, we've got to factor that in, the possibility, remote though it may be?

RHAME: Yes. You know, to me, the 2020 election is going to be a very volatile time for markets. And that's something that I just don't think has been internalized yet.

BARTIROMO: Not yet.

RHAME: Yes, not yet at all, because especially if you've got -- you know, think about the out that -- the opposite ends of the spectrum with regulation, financial regulation, health care, you name it for a Trump administration versus, you know, anybody from sort of the farther left of the spectrum, it just creates the uncertainty that could really cause businesses to shut down.

On the regulatory side, the spending side, I think the volatility we're going to see in the fourth quarter and into 2020 elections is going to be a really rocky ride for investors.

MCDOWELL: Particularly in health care.

RHAME: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Because, again, you're destroying our standard of living. If you -- if you're going to rip up health care and rip up --

FORBES: (INAUDIBLE) --

MCDOWELL: How about the -- climate change. Just -- just fighting climate change.

FORBES: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And the proposals on that, you're talking about much higher energy prices across the board for the very people who cannot afford it. I -- I don't even know -- I -- I don't even know how you begin to factor that in to any of -- into how you invest in the coming year.

RHAME: I think energy, though, it's interesting to talk about that at this juncture because the U.S. economy's relationship to energy has changed. We actually see higher energy prices in the U.S. be a positive. It really gives us -- because we produce so much of it now, some of the bigger slowdown that we had in 2015-16 was due to energy prices plunging. It was a net negative for our economy.

MCDOWELL: I'm talking about like $10 to $15 a gallon for gasoline just because -- again, you're evil if you drive a car with an internal combustion engine, because ultimately that -- at least Andrew Yang is talking about that. We're going to have to really just get rid of people owning automobiles and you're going to have rid sharing --

FORBES: Well they -- all of them just seem to get rid of people, but --

MCDOWELL: And -- and you're going to -- and we're going to have to essentially tax beef producers and farmers in this country to reduce how much we consume in terms of meat.

FORBES: And one of the ironies of this whole impeachment thing is it does take focus off of issues that are winners for Democrats, could be, like health care.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's what Dagen's saying.

But let me -- let me -- real quick before you go, the third quarter earnings are going to be here in just a couple of weeks. What's price into the market there and do you think things pick up in the fourth quarter in terms of earnings?

RHAME: I -- you know, I think third quarter -- third quarter earnings are going to be pretty sloppy and are going to set us up for a fourth quarter where we're really torn between, you know, these monetary policies, which are trying to support us, a government, which is really not able to pick up the slack on fiscal stimulus. I think we can see this tug and pull, keeping markets really wrong-footed.

BARTIROMO: All right, we'll -- well, you're -- you're on the sidelines, it sounds like, for -- in terms of investing in stocks.

RHAME: I -- I am. I think you need to manage the volatility. You need to manage the downside.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

RHAME: Choose a strategy, which helps you with that --

BARTIROMO: All right.

RHAME: Because -- yes.

BARTIROMO: All right, we've got to jump.

Lara, it's great to have you. Thanks so much. Lara Rhame joining us there.

Coming up, Facebook is under pressure again. The social media giant soon to be up against another federal anti-trust investigation. We're taking a look at big tech.

And then Alexa's vocal upgrade. An iconic actor becomes the new voice of Amazon's home assistant. We'll tell you who it is.

Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Good Thursdays morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, September 26th.

Your top stories right now, 6:32 a.m. on the East Coast.

Markets are indicating a higher opening for stock prices this morning. Take a look at futures, indicating a gain of 50 points on the Dow Industrials right out of the gate. The S&P is up four points and the Nasdaq right now up five.

Investors are waiting on the final reading of the second quarter GDP today. We will also get the latest numbers on durable goods orders tomorrow. So we've got some economic data that may very well drive markets. And this gain this morning comes on top of gains yesterday across the board. President Trump said midday that a deal with China could come sooner than expected. Markets jumped on the news, finishing up 163 points, two-thirds of 1 percent on the Dow. The S&P was up 18 and the Nasdaq up better than 1 percent, 83 points higher yesterday at 4:00 on Wall Street.

Global markets this morning are also higher. European indices higher across the board. FT 100 up 76. The CAC quarante in Paris up 38. The DAX index in Germany up 56.

In Asia overnight, markets finished mostly higher with the exception of China. As you see there, the best performer was a fractional move. In Hong Kong, up a third of a percent.

Another investigation to list for FaceBook now. The Justice Department is reportedly probing FaceBook, bringing the total to four. We're going to get into that coming up.

And then General Motors workers still on strike this morning, but the automaker and the union could be closer to a deal. We have the very latest there.

The rise of e-sports has major sports teams making big bets and big investments. We will bring you the details later this hour.

All those stories coming up this Thursday morning.

But, first, our top story this half an hour, whistleblower fallout. Acting National Intelligence Director Joseph Maguire will testify before Congress this morning on the complaint against President Trump and his call to the Ukrainian president. The president weighed in on that call yesterday at the U.N.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: It's the single greatest witch hunt in American history, probably in history, but in American history. It's a graceful thing. The letter was a great letter, meaning the letter revealing the call. That was done at the insistence of myself and other people that read it. It was a friendly letter. There was no pressure.

If you notice, the stock market went up when they saw the nonsense. All of a sudden the stock market went down very substantially yesterday when they saw a charge. After they read the charge, the stock market went up very substantially.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now is the former Whitewater independent counsel and former federal prosecutor, Robert Ray.

And, Robert, it is always a pleasure to see you.

ROBERT RAY, FORMER WHITEWATER INDEPENDENT COUNSEL: Good morning. Nice to be with you.

BARTIROMO: What's your reaction to all of this? Let's start there.

RAY: Well, the president's got it about right, it looks like the market absorbed the information and they're more concerned about China and Iran and the things that we ought to be concerned about.

BARTIROMO: Does the president have any vulnerability here? What's your take on this impeachment inquiry?

RAY: We're on a financial program. I've listened to the Democrats now for months talk about the fact that they're approaching a majority of the majority to decide whether or not to proceed with impeachment. The last time I checked, a majority of the majority does not constitute a majority of the House.

I don't actually think that the speaker has the votes yet. That's what I think.

BARTIROMO: And -- and -- and I'm sure it dies in the Senate. So let's not forget the elephant in the room. This is wasting a lot of people's time because it's not going to go anywhere in the Senate, in my view.

RAY: Well, look, impeachment, to me, is two things, based in history. You have to show both a high crime and misdemeanor, and you have to show an abuse of power. We've lived through this before. Most recently in the -- during the Clinton saga, the Clinton years.

Here, you know, they've -- from what I understand, they've tried -- first they tried treason. Well, it's not treason because, you know, somebody helpfully pointed out, Ukraine is an ally, not an enemy.

The second thing, it's not bribery because the federal bribery statute doesn't apply to foreign government officials.

Third, it's not extortion because there's no quid pro quo. And the argument that there's a quid pro quo contained in this five page transcript is a bit over the top and ridiculous unless you're going to claim that any time you're talking about foreign assistance on the one hand and asking for an investigation on the other, that that necessarily means that the one was given for the other.

And then, finally, we know now, as the result of what was disclosed yesterday, that the matter was ultimately referred to the Justice Department for investigation, a criminal referral, and the public integrity section came back and said, it's not an illegal foreign campaign contribution because, guess what, asking for an investigation is not a thing of value to the benefit of -- of Donald Trump personally. So if it's none of those things, that's zero for four, meaning -- meaning that there's no -- no crime has been committed.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

RAY: And on abuse of power, while you can argue about whether or not, you know, this telephone call was an error in judgment, ultimately at the end of the day what happened? The president released the foreign aid money and there was no untoward investigation in the Ukraine against either Hunter Biden or the vice president.

So as a result of all of this, I think as you've pointed out, what does this do? It's aimed to potentially damage the president with this continuing,, you know, diatribe about impeachment. At the same time, what does this do? It harms the vice president's campaign and so it gives the Democrats apparently what they want, which is they're going to head in the direction now of Elizabeth Warren.

BARTIROMO: Yes, get Biden out of the way.

RAY: And this is a trifecta because it then allows them also to basically, you know, have an excuse for the fact that the Democratic Congress is going to have accomplished nothing --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

RAY: In the two years of its term leading up to a presidential election. So it only sort of -- to answer your question, ultimately, it reinforces to me, since we will, within a month or so now be in the election year --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

RAY: What an exceedingly bad idea it is for the country, and not in the best interest of the country, to be conducting an impeachment proceeding in an election cycle. That's for the voters to decide.

FORBES: And then -- and you saw in the president's press conference yesterday, the Democrats were more high-handed with Ukraine than anything he did in that telephone conversation. You know, those three senators, earlier in the year, in effect implying to Ukraine, you don't do what we want to do, we're going to cut off your aid. That was overt. There was nothing subtle about that.

RAY: That's right, Steve. And even with regard to the vice president. the vice president's the only one around who -- who engaged in mafia-like tactics or strong-arm tactics against Ukraine. I mean he was bragging, as the president pointed out in the phone call about the fact that he leveraged Ukraine in order to get rid of a prosecutor they didn't think was, you know, doing his job to weed out corruption. So --

BARTIROMO: We haven't heard a lot about Tony Podesta. You know, he was lobbying for years for Ukraine. That -- that should be coming out soon. It's a real spotlight now on Hunter Biden, the Bidens and the Clintons.

RAY: Right. And, look, I mean, ultimately, as we've tried to point out for months and months and months now, they seem to be very uninterested in getting to the bottom of that. Fortunately for us, the attorney general is focused on that. That's where ultimately I think we're going to find out answers and people will be held to account.

You know, in the midst of all of this, we're -- we're wasting an enormous amount of time and burning an enormous amount of energy.

BARTIROMO: Right.

RAY: And, you know, I think, you know, at the end of the day, the voters are going to ultimately decide whether this was an overreach. Now Nancy Pelosi owns impeachment. And where we go from here is anybody's guess, but --

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's what Dagen said actually at the top of the show, yes.

MCDOWELL: I want to know, though, in the -- in the short run where this goes, with the acting director of national intelligence, Maguire, as you pointed out, testifying publicly in front of the House Intelligence Committee later today. The whistleblower complaint according to reporting has been declassified, although not yet made public.

But Senator Ben Sasse of Nebraska, who was, again, on the Senate side, has had the ability to look at it, said he found the report troubling. He said the administration ought not to be attacking the whistleblower as some talking points suggest they plan to do. "The Wall Street Journal" reports the complaint might contain additional information and is based on a series of events.

So we're going to hear from the -- I -- the public will likely get to see this. I hope everyone reads it.

DAGHER: Yes.

MCDOWELL: As they should have read the Mueller report.

But, again, how quickly does this get buttoned up, if you will, Robert?

RAY: I don't know --

MCDOWELL: This whistleblower complaint and the testimony.

RAY: I don't know because I haven't -- I haven't seen the whistleblower complaint, although other --

BARTIROMO: (INAUDIBLE) yet.

RAY: Other members of Congress have suggested, after having looked at it last night, that it really doesn't do anything other than provide corroborating details to the fact that the conversation occurred. Well, hello, we now have the conversation between the two presidents. Is there really much more to it than that? I don't know.

MCDOWELL: Yes, Ben Sasse --

BARTIROMO: See, I'm not -- I'm not surprised that the president would say, you know, look, there's corruption, we want to know what happened in 2016. A lot of op-eds this morning in "The Journal" basically saying, look, it was bad judgment. The president did not have to bring up Joe Biden's son, did not have to bring up this stuff, probably should not have gone there at all, but there was no mention in that transcript of quid pro quo.

RAY: Right.

BARTIROMO: There was no mention of aid at all.

RAY: Which apparently "The LA Times" concedes. So, you know, look, I mean, I've looked at it, too. I --

BARTIROMO: Someone call CNN and MSNBC because obviously they're not reading the actual facts.

RAY: No. And if you're listen to Ocasio-Cortez, apparently we're supposed to impeach a president based upon the fact that there's been a deviation from democratic norms, whatever the heck that means.

BARTIROMO: Right. And Nancy Pelosi, yesterday, said -- or two days ago said, it doesn't matter if there's no quid pro quo, just the fact that he brought it up is a problem for us. That's impeachable according to her.

RAY: Well, that -- that's a nice thing to say. And while the Constitution itself doesn't provide explicit guidance, you know, we do have a history here. We've been at this for 240 years. We've lived through Andrew Jackson, Andrew Johnson, Richard Nixon, Bill Clinton and now this.

BARTIROMO: Yes, but after what -- after what this president has been through where the entire country was in hysteria over potential collusion with Russia and the media was driving the bus on it, I can understand the frustration there that he wants to get to the bottom of it.

RAY: He was actually kind of whistle about that yesterday. I'm sure he'll recover from that today. But the -- the -- you know, the long and short of it is, he's right about the fact very few people would be able to actually continue to withstand this and to wake --

BARTIROMO: It's true.

RAY: And to wake up every morning, as he says, and put his suit on and go back to work.

BARTIROMO: (INAUDIBLE).

RAY: And, ultimately, the American people are going to judge this. And if - - if what happens as a result of this, that the Democrats lose control of the House, they can look back to yesterday and Nancy Pelosi's action as the reason why it occurred.

BARTIROMO: I agree.

MCDOWELL: Just really quickly. How long -- how long would this take in terms of the impeachment process?

RAY: Well, they're -- Jerry Nadler's apparently saying, oh, you know, we hope to get this done by the end of the year. I have to tell you, again, my marker is, if they haven't done anything by the date in November which constitutes the one-year marker between there and the election in 2020 --

BARTIROMO: Forget about it.

RAY: It's too late.

BARTIROMO: Too late.

RAY: So they're -- I can tell they're scrambling around trying to, you know, hustle here because they know an impeach proceeding within an election year is not in the best interest of the country.

MCDOWELL: Isn't the timing very curious.

RAY: Yes, isn't it.

BARTIROMO: And -- and if they don't get -- if they don't get USMCA done by October 21st, which is the Canada election, I don't think it gets done at all.

And, by the way, after all of this, I don't think it gets done.

RAY: Right and not --

BARTIROMO: Here we are. It doesn't get done. That's it (ph).

RAY: And this is all assuming regularity. What happens if, you know, some things that we can't foresee, you know, happen with regard to the United States on things that we should be worrying about?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

RAY: The country is going to have very little toleration for this if we've got a crisis.

BARTIROMO: Absolutely. Robert, good to see you. Thank you. Robert Ray.

RAY: Good to see you. Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: We'll be right back with the headlines.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

The General Motor strike not just affecting workers, it is starting to take a toll on customers and dealerships,

Cheryl Casone on headlines now.

Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Well, Maria, the strike has caused a shortage of parts, delaying repairs for trucks, cars and SUVs. And dealers are starting to run low on some of their models. Job action in its 11th day today. Progress is now being reported, though, at the bargaining table as GM and the United Autoworkers are looking to both end the walkout. So we'll see if we get something today on that. There's a one month chart of GM, by the way.

Ninety-five countries now have military drones. That's according to a new report from the center for the study of the drone. Back in 2010, only about 60 countries actually have them. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PALMER LUCKEY, FOUNDER, ANDURIL INDUSTRIES: The ultimate idea is to give soldiers and other first responders a perfect picture of everything that's going on around them and also a perfect picture of what's going to be happening in the near future. What's going to happen is that AI is going to be used to allow people to plan better.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Well, China Israel, and the United States are the top exporters of drones according to the report.

And Alexa has a new voice.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SAMUEL L. JACKSON, ACTOR, "SNAKES ON A PLANE": Enough is enough. I have had it with these (EXPLETIVE DELETED) snakes on this (EXPLETIVE DELETED) plane.

CASONE: A very colorful voice, indeed. Yes.

BARTIROMO: "Snakes on a Plane."

CASONE: I know. Samuel L. Jackson and other celebrities can tell you jokes, give you the weather, play music. This upgrade is going to cost 99 cents. It's available on new versions of, Maria, the Echo devices. Whether or not you get the f-bombs, I don't know, but, anyway, it's up to you, I guess.

BARTIROMO: The whole time.

FORBES: Those old (INAUDIBLE). Those old voice male (INAUDIBLE) phone services where you can put Nixon's voice in, or somebody else's voices.

BARTIROMO: Oh, yes.

FORBES: The same sort of thing. It's alive.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's very funny.

Cheryl, thank you.

CASONE: You bet.

BARTIROMO: A quick break, and then the rise of e-sports. How the gaming industry is involving the investment of major sports teams. We're going to check it out when we come back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

We are looking at the big business of e-sports. Digital sports and entertainment company New Meta Entertainment launching today. It is backed by some of the biggest sports teams, like the Philadelphia 76ers, New Jersey Devils, Houston Rockets and the Boston Bruins. The company announcing this morning is has raised $30 million in funding.

And joining us right now is the CEO of New Meta Entertainment, Michael Prindiville.

Great to see you, Michael. Thanks so much for join us.

MICHAEL PRINDIVILLE, CEO, NEW META ENTERTAINMENT: Thank you for having me. Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Congratulations.

Tell us about the company.

PRINDIVILLE: OK. The company, New Meta Entertainment, essentially a parent company. Again, the investor base, including NBA teams like the Philadelphia 76ers, the Houston Rockets, as well as NHL teams like the Devils and Bruins through Delaware North. Basically just reflecting a seismic, massive change in the world of digital sports and entertainment, right?

We used to think just about e-sports as the key for gaming. Now it's really broader than that. It's that total gaming audience. And this business effectively reflects, you know, three key parts, which is e-sports, content and investments. And, you know, at the end of the day, we are building a gaming and media company that we think reflects this systemic change in the world.

DAGHER: How come gaming is so popular among the younger folks?

PRINDIVILLE: I mean I just think it's about evolution, right?

DAGHER: Yes.

PRINDIVILLE: So we grew up in our backyard playing wiffle ball or soccer. The last 20 to 30 years, the kids have been playing video games, right? Technology has been advancing. They've been able to talk to their friends, not just in the room, but on the other side of the planet. And those form of communications, combined with the skills and the level of complexity of these games have captured an audience, captured those eyeballs and driven them away from more traditional forms of entertainment like TV and other videos on the Internet, really.

MCDOWELL: And --

FORBES: So you're going to see more things like they had in Madison Square Garden, or in South Korea, you get 40,000 people coming to these tournaments and are we going tell our kids, now grandkids, you can make a living as a video coach, as many people are doing now?

PRINDIVILLE: I think it's -- I think it's been proven, right?

DAGHER: (INAUDIBLE).

PRINDIVILLE: Like, we learned about a month ago, through the Fortnite world championships, where a young 16-year-old won $3 million, right? So --

BARTIROMO: That's right. Yes, that was great.

PRINDIVILLE: That's a nice little sum of money.

DAGHER: (INAUDIBLE), yes.

PRINDIVILLE: You know, and this -- this weekend, in Brooklyn here, ESL 1 will be packing the Barclay Center down in the Wells Fargo Center, Overwatch (ph) will be having their world championships. That will be sold out. And, you know, I happen to be getting on a plane to Berlin later tonight for the League of Legends World Champions --

BARTIROMO: Wow.

PRINDIVILLE: Which will be in -- in Europe. (INAUDIBLE), my organization will be playing in it.

MCDOWELL: Legal Legends was one of the first to really -- to do the kind of big superdome competitions.

PRINDIVILLE: That's right.

MCDOWELL: But, talk about moving away from the consoles, that -- the real gold in gaming, broadly speaking, is to like you just game on this and nothing else. You don't need to be tethered to as great as the graphics are, as great as the technology is and the visual. You can just game on your phone. You're not going to need to be tethered to an xBox or a PlayStation.

BARTIROMO: I think that's why the growth has ramped up.

MCDOWELL: Or even a computer --

PRINDIVILLE: Well, it's --

BARTIROMO: You can take it with you. It's on the go.

PRINDIVILLE: So it's pretty amazing, right? So in the world of competitive gaming, the elite form comes on a high-powered PC. People still play console. People play games on their phone.

MCDOWELL: I did say -- I did say play -- I did say PC too.

PRINDIVILLE: Of course --

MCDOWELL: So I meant like being tethered to a machine.

PRINDIVILLE: No, but I think your point was great, right, because I can be on the subway and I can see someone playing Candy Crush and you can literally go up to them and say, hey, are you a gamer? And they'll be like, ah, I'm not a gamer. Literally you -- for the last half hour you've been looking at your phone playing Candy Crush, right? We're all gamers more than we think.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: Well, congrats, Michael. We're going to be watching the developments. Thanks so much.

PRINDIVILLE: Thank you so much.

BARTIROMO: Michael Prindiville joining us there.
