urn:contentItem:5WRR-09R1-JBHT-D12R-00000-00Futures Point to Mixed Open; Facebook Sets Aside $3 Billion To Cover Expected FTC Fine; Biden Announces 2020 Run; 3M Adj. Esp Misses Estimates $2.23 (Act) Vs. $2.49 (Est); Markets Eyeing Earnings; Facebook's Earnings Beat; Shkreli Moved To Brooklyn; SoftBank Invest $125M In Alphabet's Loon; Verizon Expands 5G Service; MCD Teaming Up With AARP; Biden Announces 2020 Run; Investors Eyeing Earnings2019-04-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:52ZLexisNexisFutures Point to Mixed Open; Facebook Sets Aside $3 Billion To Cover Expected FTC Fine; Biden Announces 2020 Run; 3M Adj. Esp Misses Estimates $2.23 (Act) Vs. $2.49 (Est); Markets Eyeing Earnings; Facebook's Earnings Beat; Shkreli Moved To Brooklyn; SoftBank Invest $125M In Alphabet's Loon; Verizon Expands 5G Service; MCD Teaming Up With AARP; Biden Announces 2020 Run; Investors Eyeing EarningsLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey there, ladies, jam-packed program, good morning, everyone, happy Thursday, I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, April 25th, your top stories right now, just before 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Earnings in focus this morning, Dow Component, 3M, out later this hour, along with Southwest Airlines, whose Max 737 jets remain, grounded. The Facebook morning, this morning, the social media giant setting aside $5 billion for expected privacy violation fines. Then, Mark Zuckerberg's podcast debut as well.

Trouble for Tesla to report, the company posted big loss after a decline in Model 3 deliveries, then details on Elon Musk's new insurance program.

Carlos Ghosn could be released from jail any moment, we are waiting for details. The former Nissan chief granted bail. MORNINGS WITH MARIA begins right now.

BARTIROMO: Markets this is morning, trading -- take a look at markets this is morning, as we wait for earnings this morning, which, of course, has been setting the tone in Futures this morning, look like, really a mixed opening, is what we are expecting after yesterday's close, which was a decline.

The major technology stocks reporting yesterday, activity ahead of some earnings this morning, Facebook shares are jumping in late trading yesterday, after reporting positive first-quarter earnings, as the technology giant is also expected to face a multi-billion-dollar federal trade commission fine, Dagen is looking at that this morning. Good morning, Dagen.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria, this one time reserve $3 billion that Facebook has set aside to cover this expected Federal Trade Commission fine did eat into its earnings, more on its profits and bottom line, in a moment.

But this $3 billion is the expected fine from the FTC over privacy violations, a multi-billion-dollar penalty of this size would likely be the largest ever, against a major U.S. tech company, also the largest privacy fine in FTC history.

Why the fine? Facebook, back in 2012, agreed not to collect personal data and share it without user consent. This is part of the settlement with the FTC, but the agency has been looking into the Cambridge Analytica Scandal where the data of tens of millions of users was transferred to that -- essentially campaign firm, this data firm, during the 2016 presidential election.

So, this is a sign that the case could be winding down -- $3 billion -- the range of the expected fine was $3 to $5 billion, but FTC has not given us any deadline. Let's take a look at the earnings, earnings per share did come in higher than expected; although, profits dropped by more than half to $2.43 billion in the first quarter, in part, because of that one-time reserve wiped out most of its income.

Facebook posted $15.08 billion in revenue that was up 26 percent from the year, earlier period. Take a quick look at the stock, it is up 39 percent year to date, and it's popping an aftermarket and I quickly want to get hard rap, I will send it back to you more on the podcast, coming up.

BARTIROMO: All right. We're going to talk more about that. I know on Facebook, we've got a lot of news, Dagen, but we want to tell you that Joe Biden has, in fact, announced this morning, that he is running for president.

He just released that on Twitter, the former vice president tweeted this, the core values of this country are standing in the world, our very democracy, everything that has made America, America is at stake. That is why today, I'm announcing my candidacy for President of the United States. #Joe2020.

Joining me right now is Democratic Political Analyst, John Hopkins University Professor, Wendy Osefo, great to see you sir -- Wendy, thank you so much for joining us this morning. Your reaction, we were expecting Joe Biden to jump in and he has.

WENDY OSEFO, DEMOCRATIC POLITICAL ANALYST: He's in. And I think a lot of people have been waiting for this moment, especially on the Democratic side and now, we have the official word from him that he's in. I mean, he goes into this race, leading not only Trump, but also he's fellow Democrats in the race.

A recent POLITICO poll has him leading Trump at eight percentage points, 42 to 34. He's leading when it comes to millennials at 14 percent, when it comes to women, at 22 percent, so these are big numbers here. I think we have to look out for Iowa, New Hampshire, South Carolina. These are places where Bernie Sanders has a stronghold on New Hampshire.

Kamala Harris has a stronghold on that African-American base in South Carolina. But, overall, I think that what we see here is what the numbers alone. He has a very strong chance of winning. But I will say this, this is not going to be an easy run for him, he has to rectify issues when it comes to why did he vote to enter the Iraq war, why did he vote against busting to integrate, you know, racial equality.

There are issues that Joe Biden has to face, so this is going to be an uphill battle. But the numbers show, if we just look at the sheer demographics of this, he is the leading candidate, not just for Democrats, but for 2020, as a whole.

BARTIROMO: You know, it's interesting because some people in the party would say Bernie Sanders is the leading candidate. He's been an incredible fundraiser, even President Obama and Michelle Obama said yesterday that they are not going to vote for anybody.

They're not getting behind anybody in the primary season. They say they're going to wait for the voters to decide, and then they'll probably get behind, obviously, whoever the candidate is. Did you find that interesting that President Obama is not coming out strong behind Biden?

OSEFO: I think that what's going on right now, the Democrats is the overall arching goal, is they want someone to beat Trump. So, whoever that person is, whoever it is, they do not want to muddy the waters. They want the people to decide and vote with their feet and vote with their thoughts.

And with that being said, what they're saying here is, we're not going to back anyone because we want to make sure that when it comes to 2020, we do not have any inclination of us possibly losing. We want to make sure we win this.

So, even though, you know, Obama calls Joe Biden his brother, he does not want to get into this too early. And I think that that's actually a good approach, because myself, and as well as other Democrats and strategists, what we're saying here is whoever wins our party's nomination is who we're going to go for because that's how strongly we feel.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I know. But, I mean, does, you know, Biden need the push from Obama now, to get, you know, the lead, because this is a tight race. You know that there are --

OSEFO: Yes.

BARTIROMO: There's a radical arm of the party that wants Elizabeth Warren, that wants Bernie Sanders, to have big federal programs like Medicare-for-all and the Green New Deal, AOC, so don't you think Joe Biden needs Obama now, not to necessarily wait until the, you know, party decides?

OSEFO: I don't necessarily think so. I think that having Obama now could possibly muddy the waters because when Obama left his presidency, there were some Democrats who were not necessarily happy about things that he left on the table and did not complete.

So, even though Obama is our party favorite, I think, right now, we're just trying see what each candidate can do on their own, even though Elizabeth Warren is not necessarily leading, she is definitely the one when it comes to policy, she is one of the only few, out of the 20 Democrats, who have hard-core policies, and says this is what she's going to do.

So, you know, even though Obama would be great as far as fanfare, right now, we just want to see what each candidate is bringing to the table as far as policy.

BARTIROMO: Yes, all right. Let me ask you about the fallout from the Mueller report and whether or not this has any impact, because Hillary Clinton is out with a new op-ed in the Washington Post this morning, titled, Mueller documented a serious crime against all Americans.

Here how respond in it, she calls for Democrats to hold off on impeachment efforts, saying that the debate about how to respond to Russia's sweeping and systematic attack, and how to hold President Trump accountable for obstructing the investigation and possibly breaking the law has been reduce to a false choice: immediate impeachment or nothing.

History suggests there's a better way to think about the choices ahead.

What's your reaction to this, especially since we know that Hillary Clinton paid for the dossier, was tangled up with Russians to actually try to get dirt on Donald Trump. There's a whole investigation now going on in terms of how that investigation into Donald Trump started because it was no predicate.

We know that the FBI handled her with kid gloves, that she really wasn't investigated over her e-mail scandal. There's a story today that her e-mails actually were found in the Obama White House now, the fact that she's writing op-eds and out there on stage, talking about this, what's your reaction, Wendy?

OSEFO: I believe she's a private citizen, so she has the right to do so, even though she was former First Lady, even though she was, you know, Secretary of State, she still has the right to be a private citizen, and when it comes to the Mueller report, it's something that definitely impacts all of us.

I think that she does bring a good point, whether you sit on the left side or the right side of the aisle, which is, you know, we are faced with two choices, and those two choices are not really good ones, which is, you know, impeachment right now, or just do nothing.

I think there has to be a middle-of-the-road here because what we see from that report is something did happen, and at what point do we hold the President of the United States accountable for what the report says, and that's what she's bringing up here.

BARTIROMO: Well, we know something happened. We know that Hillary Clinton paid for the dossier.

OSEFO: No.

BARTIROMO: That they got the dossier to find out this dirt on Donald Trump, which actually was unverified and solicitous. That's what happened.

OSEFO: Well, you know, and then I can also say what happened is that the Russians went ahead and tried to interfere with our Democratic process, in favor of Donald J. Trump. And that is an issue, and that is something that not only affects Hillary Clinton, as well as Donald Trump, that's something that affects 2020, whether we're going to make sure that whoever goes forward for 2020, we do not allow a power like Russia, a nefarious power, to interfere in our Democratic process --

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's interesting, because we knew -- we knew that Russia was trying to meddle into the west's dealings back in 2012 and 2014, why do you think President Obama and Hillary Clinton never did anything about it?

OSEFO: I think he did try to do something about it, I definitely do. I do believe that it's not something that was finished, that's what I'm saying about, you know, there's certain people on the left side that have issues with what happened with Obama and the things that he left on the table.

BARTIROMO: Right.

OSEFO: But I do believe that now that Trump is in office, that he is the President of the United States, the question then becomes what is he currently doing about it? And right now, there's nothing he's doing about it, and that is an issue.

BARTIROMO: All right. Wendy, thanks very much, we're going to keep following this.

OSEFO: Thank you so much.

BARTIROMO: Of course, Joe Biden is on Twitter, he is officially in the race, running for president. Joining me right now on the telephone is Mark Penn, he is Senior Adviser to the -- he was Senior Adviser to the Clintons, he is the President of the Stagwell Group, and Mark, it's always great to have you here, what's your reaction to Joe Biden jumping in here?

MARK PENN, PRESIDENT, STAGWELL GROUP (through telephone): Well, I think that he's jumping in clearly as a values-oriented moderate (INAUDIBLE) at his announcement, he's not -- he's not stressing Medicare-for-All, Green New Deal, he's stressing at those he's concerned about the middle class. He's concerned about climate change. He's got real concern about equality.

So, he seemed like he's got a history of having been a vice president, stood side by side with President Obama, so he's coming out to say, I have values, I think that -- and he says that Trump is off, in terms -- in terms of the values. I'm really going to fight for the middle class and for equality.

I really work for Obama. And by inference, he's coming in as a moderate to take out that crowd. The values (INAUDIBLE) first person we've seen enter lately, who's really staked out this ground.

BARTIROMO: Yes, you know, it's a good point in terms of the moderate point that you make, because there's this radical arm in Democratic Party, as you know.

Do you think he's going to be able to push through and be the candidate, even as you've got people like Bernie Sanders raising so much money and coming up with socialist programs, Elizabeth Warren also, really radical on the left, AOC, is he going to be able to have his voice heard, in a moderate way?

PENN: Well, even though he hasn't been in the race, he's been -- he's been polling number one, he has a constituency, you know, somewhat more than a third. His problem is that constituency may or may not be in Iowa, it certainly is in the kind of broad big states, where Democrats, you know, particularly the Northeastern states, he's got, I think, a real constituency throughout the party.

He's not going to easily win and he's not going to be easily beaten. There's a lot fire and energy behind Sanders, right now, and some of the -- some of the new exciting candidates, but you know -- you know, he's got a reasonable chance here. He's clearly in the top 3, and we'll see how he gets out of the gate.

But he's clearly staked out to me, a ground that's moderate, that's not as radical, that says, hey, I'm an alternative who's going to bring sensible policies that will fit to the middle class, and you know, that at least gives Democrats a real choice.

BARTIROMO: What do you think about President Obama saying that he's going stay on the sidelines? That he's not going to endorse anybody during primary race? I mean, here we have Joe Biden, his former vice president, jumping in the race, and his former partner, President Obama, is not going to be there to endorse him.

PENN: Well, I think like it or not, Obama has said clearly, I thought that he thinks that Biden was a great vice president, but he's not necessarily endorsing him as the -- as the -- as the person who should be the next president, and I think he's always been clear about that.

I think he's -- and he said he's going to, kind of, sit back and not take an active role in this campaign, and you know, that's always disappointing when you served somebody for that many years, but there is something of a history in that. Remember (INAUDIBLE) Nixon?

BARTIROMO: Interesting. All right, Mark, thanks so much, we will see you soon, Mark Penn, more on Joe Biden's entry in the 2020 race when we come back. Plus, Carlos Ghosn may be released from prison, all that next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Well, we have breaking news this morning, it is official, Joe Biden has entered the 2020 presidential race, joining the conversation this morning, Assistant Editorial Page Editor at the Wall Street Journal, James Freeman is here, along with PWC Partner Mitch Roschelle, good morning, gentlemen.

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, WALL STREET JOURNAL: Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction, Joe Biden in the race, James.

FREEMAN: Yes, can be interesting to see who he is as a candidate this time, does he want to show how woke he is, in which case, I think you'd say what's the point of the candidacy, or is he going to stake out that moderate pro-business path that a lot of check writers in the city, on the Democratic side, are hoping for.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's a good point, the check writers.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PARTNER, PWCUS: It should be interesting to see if we re-litigate the last, you know, the eight years of the Obama administration. That becomes the really big issue.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Here's Joe Biden, breaking the news.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOE BIDEN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I believe history will look back on four years of this president, and all he embraces as an aberrant moment in time. But if we give Donald Trump eight years in the White House, he will forever and fundamentally alter the character of this nation, who we are, and I cannot stand-by and watch that happen.

The core values of this nation are standing in the world, our very democracy, everything that has made America, America is at stake. That's why today, I'm announcing my candidacy for President of the United States. Folks America is an idea. An idea that's stronger than any army, bigger than any ocean, more powerful than any dictator or tyrant. It gives hope to the most desperate people on Earth.

It guarantees that everyone is treated with dignity. And gives hate no safe harbor. It instills in every person in this country the belief that no matter where you start in life, there's nothing you can't achieve if you work at it. That's what we believe. And above all else that's what's at stake in this election.

We can't forget what happened in Charlottesville. Even more important, we have to remember who we are. This is America.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And with that, the 2020 race is on, your reaction, Dagen?

MCDOWELL: That someone -- big Democratic voter described Joe Biden as a mensch. And I think that that is really somebody who's thoughtful and caring, and I think that's going to have to come out.

Also, he's got the ability to kind of swoop in when Medicare-for-All is kind of the phrase of the moment which, again, eradicates private insurance in the country, and just come in and say I want to sure up Obamacare. Here are my fixes for it. It's working. I don't want to change it -- change it too much.

Here is how we're going to fix this. Again, you are banned from using the word, woke, ever again, James Freeman.

FREEMAN: Sorry.

MCDOWELL: I noticed that there was a quick clip of Martin Luther King in that video. And I will point out that Bernie Sanders was booed at this She the People Summit.

BARTIROMO: I think it was yesterday, for name-dropping Martin Luther King, Jr., saying I was on -- I marched on Washington with Dr. King and he got booed. It was very uncomfortable. He kept putting his finger up like that.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

MCDOWELL: So, again, Joe Biden brings in something to the Democratic nomination race that other people don't have.

BARTIROMO: Is he going to be able to push through that will pass these radicals?

FREEMAN: Yes, I --

MCDOWELL: Because he's not a radical.

BARTIROMO: Right.

MCDOWELL: Right.

FREEMAN: Yes. Well, we will see, we will see what the -- what the Biden 2020 looks like. I think -- I think he has an opportunity, but it's a question about that 25 or 30 percent that gets in every poll of Democrats, is that name I.D., is that Obama nostalgia, or is it this hunger that we hear in this city for economic sanity in the Democratic field?

BARTIROMO: Even as Obama is not endorsing him. I find that really odd that President Obama and Michelle said yesterday, they're going to stay on the sidelines. They're not going to get behind any Democratic candidate.

MCDOWELL: But that was -- that was something that in Democratic circles was known. That President Obama and Michelle were not going to come out and endorse anybody, not until it was pretty clear who the nominee would be.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll take a short break. When we come back, more on Joe Biden's entry into 2020 race this morning, plus Carlos Ghosn may be released from prison this morning. We're going to have the details when we come back, stay with us.

ANNOUNCER: Trump to send troops. The President declares he'll bring armed soldiers south, but will the American people be on board with the border move? Tom Homan breaks it all down on "DOBBS".

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, it is official this morning, Joe Biden has entered the 2020 presidential race, we have more coming up throughout the morning on this, but first, we want to get to headlines, Carlos Ghosn could be released from Tokyo jail this morning, Cheryl Casone with more details there and headlines, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: We're monitoring any breaking news out of Japan, Maria, the former Nissan chairman has been granted bail for a second time, after being arrested back in November, on charges of financial conduct.

Ghosn will walk out after posting that $4-1/2 million in bail. He continues to deny the charges against him, including this latest one, a breach of trust for allegedly diverting $5 million of Nissan money.

Well, Deutsche Bank has ended merger talks with Commerce Bank, we got that news this morning, a deal expected to be announced as soon as Friday. The Wall Street Journal reports the agreement lack investor support and opposition from the Labor Unions.

A merger between the two ailing banks would have created Germany's largest financial institution, but that'll all change today.

Slack technologies moving forward with plans to go public, on the New York Stock Exchange, the Wall Street Journal reports the company expected to reveal its prospectus soon. Slack is one of the latest tech companies that's looking to make its trading debut during a really hot IPO market, through a direct listing, which doesn't require raising money or using underwriters.

So, we'll see if we get that news as well. So, we are watching any, of course, any pictures out of Japan, Maria, we'll bring them to you if we get them.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and Slack has been talked about, a lot of excitement about that deal.

CASONE: Yes.

BARTIROMO: So, we'll watch that as well, Cheryl, thank you so much.

CASONE: You bet.

BARTIROMO: We've got a lot going on this morning certainly with Biden, entering the race, as well as other news around the Mueller report, what are you following this morning, your reaction, James?

FREEMAN: Yes. I think the Biden candidacy is interesting, see if it creates a much-up problem for Trump in the Midwest. Biden moved out of Scranton, Pennsylvania during the Eisenhower administration, but if he -- if he tasked himself as speaking for blue-collared voters, might create a problem for Trump in the Midwest.

MCDOWELL: But you raised this issue as well, in terms of all of the other candidates being further left and Joe Biden for the most part. I think that Tim Ryan is the only one -- other one who's a real moderate. But he's going to have to answer to the Democratic primary voters on issues like he voted for the crime bill, he voted for welfare reform, he voted for repeal Glass-Steagall, as well.

So, he's got such a long history in the Senate. There's a -- there's a lot for them to use against him, a lot of mud to swing in his direction.

BARTIROMO: And there are so many radicals in the race right now, on the Democratic side.

ROSCHELLE: And the question is, if you look at Midterms, suburban voters really made a difference, and Joe Biden could very well appeal to those suburban voters and some of these radicals probably don't.

BARTIROMO: Yes. All right, we'll take a short break. When we come back, a lot more coming up, Joe Biden is in the 2020 presidential race, the former vice president, adding his name to the crowded Democratic field this morning. We've got all of the rollout highlights coming up. He's calling it the values of his campaign. We'll bring those to you.

And then, golden arches for golden years, details on McDonald's new partnership with AARP, back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, April 25th.

We have "BREAKING NEWS" this morning. It is now official, Joe Biden has entered the 2020 presidential race. We will talk with former DNC chair, Donna Brazile, this morning about what his candidacy means to the already crowded field of contenders, coming up.

Earnings in focus, of course, Wall Street, Dow component, 3M with the earnings in moments along with Southwest Airlines, whose fleet of 737 MAX jets remain grounded.

After develop tonight, we will hear from Amazon as well as Ford Motor and Starbucks who are bringing all of those numbers. And full analysis coming up.

Markets this morning look like this. Take a look at the Futures indicating a mixed story at the start of trading. Dow Futures are down 56 points, quarter of a percent. But the S&P Futures up a quarter, and the NASDAQ up 14-1/2 right now.

Yesterday, a market snapped a three-day winning streak. Take a look at the S&P and the NASDAQ. Yesterday, we saw the markets retreating from record highs reversing any gains by the closed. Dow Industrials are down 59 points. And the S&P 500, down 6-1/2. The NASDAQ down 18 points.

In Europe this morning here's the action right now. And it is lower across the board. FT-100, down 25 points. CAC Quarante in Paris is down 9-1/2. And the DAX index in Germany down 2-1/2 points. Fractional moves there, but lower.

In Asia overnight, take a look at the numbers where Japan was higher, but the Shanghai Composite in China down two and a half percent that really set the tone for markets. The Bank of Japan said that it will hold rates at zero until spring of 2020. There is concern about slowing growth, reaching its two percent inflation objective in Japan.

Southwest Airlines is hitting the tape right now. As you can see, the earnings at $0.70 share, versus an estimates, $0.61 a share. That's better than expected. Revenue also better than expected.

Ashley Webster is on this news right now. He is checking on earnings for the first quarter. Ashley, over to you.

KANTROWITZ: We would be fading semiconductors and other various cyclical groups like autos, even I think housing, which has benefited from the big drop in interest rates. I think we've gotten the max benefit, if you will, from the drop in rates. If interest rates continue falling from here, or if the fed gets more dovish, we don't think that's going to be something that'll support the equity market because it'll likely happen because of a disappointment in economic activity.

BARTIROMO: So people will basically view the Federal Reserve lowering rates as an indication that things are pretty slow.

KANTROWITZ: Sure. If the fed were to cut rates, which is not our near term view, that something bad has likely happened and the markets are likely lower ahead of that.

BARTIROMO: Uh-huh.

KANTROWITZ: We think it's quite a high bar for the fed to lower rates today.

BARTIROMO: Tell me about the commodities part of things, this report on timber and lumber. What is that telling us?

KANTROWITZ: Sure. When we look at lumber prices, it's a phenomenal -- has a phenomenal fit with actual -- as a leading indicator of earnings growth, PMIs, which is something we focus on as another measure of a leading indicator. And lumber prices are down about 60 percent year-over-year, one of the biggest drops actually going back to the early '90s. And so historically, that's been a good foreshadowing of a continued weakness in leading indicators --

BARTIROMO: So --

KANTROWITZ: -- which would portend further downward revisions for earnings.

BARTIROMO: Would that indicate weakness in the housing sector? Obviously wood and --

KANTROWITZ: It could. Sure. Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- in terms of construction.

KANTROWITZ: Yes. Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And are there any other indicators like that like iron, or -- that you would -- that you would point to for further indication of that?

KANTROWITZ: Lumber prices are more of coincident indicator. When we try to figure out -- figure out where earnings momentum in the economy is going and ultimately where you want to be positioned within the market? We look at things that lead, things like the industrial production report like we got or the durables report we got today.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KANTROWITZ: And that's -- there tends to be things like monetary policy. So, yes, the feds raise rates, they are done but kind of like when you have a big meal, you don't feel -- you don't get that stomachache until an hour after you've eaten that meal.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KANTROWITZ: And so the fed kind of stopped eating, if you will, but we still think there is a stomachache if you will for the economy in the next couple of quarters.

BARTIROMO: Real quick, in terms of that slowdown that you're expecting second half of the year, will the markets take a cue from that? Do you want to buy stocks here or do you want to sell given the fact that you are expecting the backdrop to weaken?

KANTROWITZ: Sure. So the market's gone up entirely on P/E expansion, which has been a function of reducing the risks around the fed, tariffs, the dollar, which is now beginning to move up again, so that could become a risk. And the global slowdown, which we think will continue into the end of this year. And so P/Es aren't going to help anymore, and so you're now back to earnings. We think earnings are going to disappoint so I think the market is for the year is about as high as it's going to get. Could go higher a little bit, sure, but I would actually be moving more into groups that are beneficiaries of a slowdown or disappointment, such as staples, utilities, health care, still sticking with some high quality tech growth names, those will do better than other cyclical names.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will it there. Michael, great to have you on the show.

KANTROWITZ: All right. Thank you so much, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so muck. Michael Kantrowitz, Cornerstone Macro. Coming up, eye on Amazon this evening. The retail giant reporting earnings today after the closing. Stuart Varney will weigh in on that with his expectations. Then glamor meets camping, we are taking a look into the big business glamping, a luxury camping experience that lets you experience great outdoors without the work, back in a minute with that, stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: The big business of Amazon, the retail giant reporting earnings after the bell. Joining me now, the host of "VARNEY & CO." Stuart Varney to weigh in. Stu, good morning.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: I just wonder, Maria, if Amazon will take its cue from Microsoft and Facebook which, this morning, are zooming after their very positive earnings reports yesterday. Now I'm not leading anybody on here. I am suggesting though that if Amazon comes out with blowout earnings, they could be headed very sharply higher just like Microsoft and Facebook. I've got a caveat here, though, one of the reasons that Microsoft is up so sharply is that their cloud business performed so very well. Up 73 percent, as I -- as I'm reading the numbers. Well, Amazon is big in the cloud business as well. They're a direct competitor with Microsoft for the cloud industry, so to speak.

If Microsoft is doing so well, does that mean that Amazon is not doing so well in the cloud? And if that's the case, then the stock probably won't zoom as much as it might other things being the same, so I'm really looking forward to seeing what happens this afternoon. The indication is, I'm looking on the board now, Amazon's up about 20 bucks at $19.22. I just wonder if there is a blowout report, they're doing well in the cloud, do they hit $2,000 today or tomorrow morning? Which is it? I'm just wondering.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

VARNEY: Just saying. Just saying.

BARTIROMO: Can you believe this stock price, $1,900?

VARNEY: Well, it's been above 2,000 before.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: Looks set to get back to that. And --

BARTIROMO: I wonder why they don't split it, Stu.

VARNEY: Yes. I -- I've never understood that. I don't know.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: I mean look at Google, $1,200 a share. Back in the day, you know 10 years ago, you split when you got to about $80.00, $90.00, $100 a share.

BARTIROMO: Yes, you're right.

VARNEY: That was kind of normal.

BARTIROMO: It's true.

VARNEY: Also Berkshire Hathaway stood out, it went up to, what, 40,000 or something.

BARTIROMO: That's incredible.

VARNEY: I just don't know what else --

BARTIROMO: And let's -- and let's not forget where Google went public. What was it, $75.00?

VARNEY: Something like that.

BARTIROMO: I think it was $75.00. They -- remember they did that --

VARNEY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- that public offering that they didn't use, banks traditionally the way that regular IPOs are done?

VARNEY: Yes. Yes. Yes.

BARTIROMO: And here it is at 1,273.

VARNEY: Who -- and I cannot understand why they don't split.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: I just don't get that.

BARTIROMO: That's a good point. Stu, I know you'll have a lot more in 15 minutes. We'll see you at the top of the hour.

VARNEY: Sure thing.

BARTIROMO: Thank you. "VARNEY & CO." begins top of the hour every day, 9:00 a.m. Eastern right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA so stay with us for that. But first, Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank are scrapping the merger talks. Cheryl's on that right now in headlines. Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Another big story this morning, Maria. An announcement on the Deutsche Bank-Commerzbank deal was expected as soon as tomorrow, but Wall Street Journal has reported the agreement lacked investor support and it faced its opposition from labor unions. The merger between the two struggling banks would have created Germany's largest financial institution.

Well, out of japan, Carlos Ghosn could be released from a Tokyo jail today. The former Nissan Chairman has been granted bail for a second time, after being arrested back in November on charges of financial misconduct. Now he continues to deny all charges against him including the latest concerning breach of trust for allegedly diverting $5 million in Nissan money. And sources telling Maria Bartiromo once Ghosn's released, he won't be able to see or communicate with his wife, Carole, as part of his bail agreement.

Now Maria, when you spoke with Carole Ghosn last week, she told you her husband is in poor health. Well, some music for concert lovers, ears to mark National Concert Week next week, Live Nation is offering quite a deal and selling tickets for just 20 bucks. The bargain, good for more than 2,800 concerts across the country. The tickets go on sale, get ready, Wednesday, May 1st. All right. Coming up, gone glamping, a look into the big business of luxury camping. How to surely make you a happy camper, it's coming up next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We are coming to you from outside in the plaza here at FOX. The woods will never be the same, a new high end camping experience provided by Brooklyn-based Terra Glamping. Joining me right now is Terra Glamping CEO and Co-Founder, Rebecca Martin. And Rebecca, it's great to have you. Thanks so much for joining us.

REBECCA MARTIN, CEO, TERRA GLAMPING: Thank you for having us.

BARTIROMO: Love Brooklyn and love the idea of this glamping, so that's glamorous camping.

MARTIN: Correct. Yes. And we're Brooklyn-based, which is where you would think all of your outdoor companies are from, but we do -- we provide luxury glamping for -- in a hotel setting and also for special events all around the country.

BARTIROMO: That is very cool.

MARTIN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: This tent is so beautiful. Let's go in and take a look at some of the features that we've got here. Hello there. Oh, wow. Tell me about this.

MARTIN: So these are our sleeping tents that we have at our glamping hotels, and all of the tents have memory foam mattresses, and beautiful bedding on them, so that when you're -- you can sleep outdoors and you can have that fresh air wafting through, but you can be comfortable. You don't have to worry about sticks and bumps. We have everything that you need from, you know, face wash, and sunscreen to cell phone chargers and books. So it's like a hotel room right inside here.

BARTIROMO: This is very cool. So, you know what, I actually -- I needed this one. I stayed overnight in the Sahara Desert and I was freezing all night. What about the temperature? Because when I was in a tent, it was so cold I had to wear like three or four layers. Is there some kind of a heating mechanism in here or no?

MARTIN: So the beds. The beds themselves are incredibly warm, they will heat up to your body temperature at night, and then we have down comforters on top of those. We often have people who will say, "Oh, I'm going to be freezing tonight." Go in layers and then they strip it off in the middle of the night because the beds are so incredibly warm.

BARTIROMO: Oh, OK. What is the benefit of glamping versus camping? Tell me about that.

MARTIN: So the benefit of being outdoors, the benefit of disconnecting from the crazy, busy world that we're always in right now, so we're always on our phones, we're always, you know, at work, and this way we can be in nature, but you don't have to lose the creature comforts. There are a lot of people who --

BARTIROMO: They look nice.

MARTIN: Yes, thank you.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MARTIN: There are a lot of people who don't want to be outdoors and this is a great way to open it up to so many more people.

BARTIROMO: And you are opening it up this summer.

MARTIN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: You've got plans to be out in New York. East Hampton?

MARTIN: East Hampton.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Tell me about that.

MARTIN: So 30 tents, we're going to have, and East Hampton right on Gardiners Bay, so we're looking out on the water, to Sag Harbor, and we have the sleeping tents, we have a dining tent, lounge tents, we have kayaks, and standup paddleboards.

BARTIROMO: I love this idea. That's fun. How much is that -- the whole experience if somebody wanted to get into this tent on -- in East Hampton for a weekend in the summer?

MARTIN: So Terra Glamping East Hampton, it starts $300 a night for this room, and weekends are two-night minimum on there, but you get breakfast as well, you know, the campfire, and a gourmet smorgasbord every night.

BARTIROMO: Oh my goodness.

MARTIN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: That's terrific. So what's the reception been so far?

MARTIN: Reception's been great.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MARTIN: Yes. I mean it's a trend, I think, that that's going to come more mainstream.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MARTIN: Been in the business for five years at the infancy in America and it's just more and more companies are coming out. People understanding. I don't have to explain glamping anymore to people, so --

BARTIROMO: I guess -- I guess in the summer time, it's OK because the weather is nice.

MARTIN: Right.

BARTIROMO: And you won't be that cold.

MARTIN: Right.

BARTIROMO: It's sort of like an Airbnb but in a tent.

MARTIN: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: Love it. Rebecca, great to have you.

MARTIN: Yes. Yes. Thank you so much.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Check it out, Rebecca Martin. We'll be right back, stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: All right. Welcome back. We're coming to you from outside the plaza. Hey, thanks for coming out this morning.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Great to see everybody. Let's get some final thoughts from our all-star panel. How'd you guys like the glamorous tent? Over to you, Mitch. Final thoughts.

ROSCHELLE: I did like the glamorous tent. Durable Goods Orders came out earlier at 2.7 percent, which was way ahead of expectations. Tomorrow, we have GDP, which could also exceed expectations. So, maybe the rumors of the demise of the U.S. economy were greatly exaggerated and we're starting off to a good start in 2019.

BARTIROMO: I'd have to agree with that. James, what do you say?

FREEMAN: Yes. American exceptionalism. So far, kind of cool. We'll look forward to tomorrow. I like glamping as well. I have a feeling Mrs. Freeman would especially like glamping.

BARTIROMO: Dagen?

MCDOWELL: All right. So my favorite story out this morning, I just saw this on Axios, this is of course given that Vice President Joe Biden is now officially running for the Democratic nomination, former Democratic Senators Heidi Heitkamp and Joe Donnelly have a plan to teach 2020 candidates how to talk to a Trump voter. How to talk to rural voters. These two individuals, Heitkamp and Joe Donnelly couldn't even hold their Senate seats in their own states but they're going to tell other candidates how to win over voters. That was the biggest belly laugh for me all morning so far.

BARTIROMO: Unbelievable. Great analysis, as always. Great to see you, guys. Thanks so much for joining us. It's been a show of breaking news throughout the morning. Have a great day, everybody. A big hello to Stuart Varney as we toss over to him.

VARNEY: Yes. Yes.

BARTIROMO: Over to you, Stu, and "VARNEY & CO."

VARNEY: All right, Maria, thank you very much indeed.

END

urn:contentItem:60N4-TYV1-JCMN-Y3J1-00000-00Futures Tumble, Dollar Soars After European PMIs Slump, Putting Recovery In Doubt2020-08-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:51ZLexisNexisFutures Tumble, Dollar Soars After European PMIs Slump, Putting Recovery In DoubtZero Hedge

Aug 21, 2020( Phil's Stock World: http://www.philstockworld.com Delivered by Newstex) Courtesy of ZeroHedge[1] View original post here[2]. US stock index futures dropped, tracking European markets a day after the tech-heavy Nasdaq closed at a record high, as optimism in a virus-vaccine breakthrough and faith in the record tech rally was challenged by concerns over an unexpected frop in Eurozone PMIs which put the biggest recovery narrative in recent months in doubt. Among US stocks, Deere & Co rose 4.5% premarket after it revised up its full-year earnings forecast and reported a smaller-than-expected decline in quarterly profit. Pfizer rose 1.5% after reporting positive additional data from an early-stage study of its experimental coronavirus vaccine being developed in collaboration with German biotech firm BioNTech. U.S.-listed shares of BioNTech jumped 8.1%. Tesla gained another 1.8% after surging past the $2,000 mark on Thursday for the first time and extending its rally ahead of an upcoming share split.

US stocks finished higher on Thursday as investors continued to bet on tech heavyweights including Apple and Amazon.com to ride out the pandemic as U.S. data painted a picture of a wobbly economic recovery. However the market's bad breadth is getting extremely narrow: yesterday stocks closed green even though 70% of all companies closed in the red. U.S. tech darlings "continue to mask the broader concerns spearheading an end-of-week rally," saidNema Ramkhelawan-Bhana, head of research at Johannesburg-based Rand Merchant Bank. "Wider credit spreads and bond bidding suggest an air of nervousness is starting to creep in." Joe Biden accepted his party'snominationThursday to challenge President Donald Trump in a speech that cast November's election as not merely the choice of a president but a fundamental referendum on the nation's character. Europeanstocks and the euro slumped after European PMI composite readings unexpectedly declined in August from July, missing expectations even as U.K. data was materially stronger (UK flash composite PMI 60.3 vs 57; est. 56.9). Job losses were a notable feature of the surveys. As Goldman writes, after a record, better-than-expected cumulative improvement of 41.2pt over May-July, the Euro area composite PMI declined by 3.3pt to 51.6 in August, notably below expectations. The overall decline was heavily skewed towards the service sector, with the manufacturing PMI little changed from July. Across countries, the German and French composite PMIs were also weaker than expected, with the sequential weakening in France broad-based across sectors but solely concentrated in services in Germany. The implicit decline in the composite PMI outside of France and Germany was only marginally smaller than the decline in the Franco-German composite PMI. The weakening in the PMIs suggests that the pace of sequential growth has moderated as the gap in the level of activity relative to pre-Covid narrows (consistent with high-frequency activity indicators): Euro Area Composite PMI (August, Flash): 51.6, consensus 55.0, last 54.9. Euro Area Manufacturing PMI (August, Flash): 51.7, consensus 52.7, last 51.8. Euro Area Services PMI (August, Flash): 50.1, consensus 54.5, last 54.7. Germany Composite PMI (August, Flash): 53.7, consensus 55.0, last 55.3. France Composite PMI (August, Flash): 51.7, consensus 57.0, last 57.3. The broader miss was led by France whose manufacturing PMI unexpectedly dropped in August after a two-month rebound. The sharp fall put in doubt the country's recovery and led to a decline in the euro. Meanwhile Germany's recovery also lost momentum, with mixed PMI figures. PMI for services declined while manufacturing continued to improve Earlier in the session, Asian stocks gained, led by communications and IT, after falling in the last session. Most markets in the region were up, with Taiwan's Taiex Index gaining 2% and South Korea's Kospi Index rising 1.3%, while Australia's S&P/ASX 200 dropped 0.1%. The Topix gained 0.3%, with Fujikyu and TSUNAGU GROUP HOLDINGS I rising the most. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.5%, with Whirlpool China and Ningbo Jifeng Auto Parts posting the biggest advances. Earlier this week, the S&P 500 clinched a record high, recouping the last of its losses caused by the coronavirus-driven slump and joining the Nasdaq in notching new highs even as investors remained on edge over a stalemate in talks between House Democrats and the White House over the next coronavirus aid bill as about 28 million Americans continued to collect unemployment checks. There was some hope that a deal would be reached tomorrow when a $25BN post office spending proposal is considered. In FX, the dollar gained against a basket of its peers largely thanks to a sharp drop in the Euro which reversed an early gain that came at the back of hopes over a coronavirus vaccine after the latest PMI data challenged the narrative that euro area growth will outperform the US; the EURUSD slumped after data showed French manufacturing unexpectedly contracted in August after a two- month rebound; German and euro area data also missed expectations. The common currency retreated as much as 0.6% to 1.1780. The euro poised for first weekly drop in nine; interbank desks fade the dip given Thursday's rebound after 21-DMA support held, yet short-term traders look for a move toward 1.1750, three traders in Europe said. The offshore yuan rose to its strongest level in seven months against the dollar, as China's economic and market rebound from the pandemic has proved one of the world's fastest. Elsewhere, Turkey's lira gained amid speculation President Recep Tayyip Erdogan willannouncea major Turkish energy discovery in the Black Sea later Friday. In rates, Treasuries advanced while Europeanbond yields were flat to 1bp lower across the curves; the 10Y Treasury yield dropped -3bp to 0.6282%, flattening the 2s-10s curve. German 2-yr, 10-yr yields 1bp lower. In commodities, Brent ($44.72) and WTI ($42.57) traded lower but were on track for a third weekly gain in New York trading. Gold slumped to $1920 as the dollar surged. Looking ahead, expected data include PMIs and existing home sales. Deere is reporting earnings Market Snapshot S&P 500 futures little changed at 3,380.00 MXAP up 0.8% to 170.76 MXAPJ up 0.9% to 562.42 Nikkei up 0.2% to 22,920.30 Topix up 0.3% to 1,604.06 Hang Seng Index up 1.3% to 25,113.84 Shanghai Composite up 0.5% to 3,380.68 Sensex up 0.8% to 38,515.19 Australia S&P/ASX 200 down 0.1% to 6,111.18 Kospi up 1.3% to 2,304.59 STOXX Europe 600 up 0.3% to 366.72 German 10Y yield fell 1.1 bps to -0.507% Euro down 0.4% to $1.1813 Italian 10Y yield unchanged at 0.789% Spanish 10Y yield fell 0.2 bps to 0.289% Brent futures down 0.7% to $44.59/bbl Gold spot down 0.8% to $1,932.61 U.S. Dollar Index up 0.2% to 92.98 Top US News from Bloomberg France's manufacturing PMI unexpectedly dropped in August after a two-month rebound. The sharp fall put in doubt the country's recovery and led to a decline in the euro. Meanwhile Germany's recovery lost momentum, with mixed PMI figures. PMI for services declined while manufacturing continued to improve Composite PMI fell below estimates in the euro-area. The U.K. economy rebounded to a seven-year high, with composite PMI performing better than expected, while retail sales for July beat estimates, pushing the pound upwards momentarily Global market snapshot courtesy of NewsSquawk:[3] Asian equity markets traded mostly positive as the region benefitted from the tech-led gains on Wall St where Apple prodded above the USD 2tln market cap status and as firm gains in Tesla, Microsoft, Intel and Facebook also fuelled the big tech resurgence resulting to outperformance in the Nasdaq, although upside was capped in the broader market amid mixed data releases including higher than expected Initial Jobless Claims. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) both initially took impetus from the constructive handover from US peers but with upside in Australia later retraced following soft PMI data and with weakness seen in defensives as well as the top-weighted financials sector, while the Japanese benchmark contended with the effects of a mixed currency and resistance at the 23,000 level. Hang Seng (+1.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.5%) were underpinned amid the continued PBoC liquidity efforts in which it injected CNY 150bln through 7-day reverse repos and CNY 50bln in 14-day reverse repos. This was the first occasion the central bank utilized the latter instrument in around 2 months, and there was also recent confirmation from China's MOFCOM that the US and China will be conducting the delayed trade discussions in the approaching days. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat and continue to eye the 152.00 level to the upside despite the gains in Japanese stocks, with mild support provided by the BoJ's presence in the market for JPY 870bln of JGBs and the central bank also offered to purchase JPY 200bln in corporate bonds from 25th August with a remaining 3-5yrs to maturity. Top Asian News Pressure Grows on Hong Kong to Re-Open Economy as Cases Drop Hong Kong to Start Virus Testing Blitz of Whole City on Sept. 1 India Slaps New Curbs on Visas, Schools to Stem China Influence Millions Escaped Caste Discrimination. Covid-19 Brought It Back European equities (Eurostoxx 50 +0.3%) have held onto opening gains despite a brief dip lower in the wake of French PMI metrics. However, the pessimism surrounding the August outturn for France was short-lived for broader European assets with equities paring declines ahead of the German release. The German release painted a slightly less downbeat picture with a firmer manufacturing outturn alongside a softer than expected services, with the eventual EZ-wide release posting a miss on expectations for both sectors but ultimately remaining in expansionary territory. IHS Markit noted 'the eurozone stands at a crossroads, with growth either set to pick back up in coming months or continue to falter following the initial post-lockdown rebound'. Nonetheless, sentiment for European equities remains afloat in what has been a relatively choppy week in terms of price action for the region. Sectoral performance in Europe is broadly firmer with the exception of energy names which are tracking crude prices lower. Travel & Leisure names are faring the best thus far with some reprieve been granted to the likes of Ryanair (+1.6%) and easyJet (+1.4%), however, with the UK continuing to add more countries to its quarantine list (albeit, has removed Portugal), it's difficult to see how much conviction will be placed upon a recovery in the sector. Elsewhere, individual movers include Kingspan (+7.4%) post-earnings, Wirecard (+5.4%) amid reports that it has found a suitor for its UK assets, whilst Accor (+2.6%) shares continue to remain supported alongside talk of a potential bid for InterContinental Hotels. To the downside, laggards are relatively sparse with Maersk (-2.8%) and Saipem (-2%) lower on the day following downgrades at JP Morgan Chase and Bernstein respectively. Top European News Europe's Economic Recovery Stumbles After Initial Bounceback U.K. Economy Rebounds With Activity Rising to Seven-Year High Pessimism Returns to Brexit Talks as Hopes for Deal Slip Away Advent Said to Mull Over $1.2 Billion Sale of Health Firm Mediq In FX, sub-par French Flash PMIs triggered the losses in the Single Currency, with the French manufacturing metric surprisingly falling back into contraction, whilst Germany and EZ held their heads above the 50 threshold, but largely missed forecasts. EUR/USD has receded from its 1.1882 high and took out an interim support area around 1.1840-45 to test 1.1800 to the downside. Participants will now be eyeing any updates on the Belarus front in regard to sanctions, with little on the docket in terms of scheduled events. Conversely, UK Retail Sales and PMIs topped forecasts across the board but gains Sterling were short-lived as the currency succumbs to the Buck, whilst Brexit talks remain in limbo as officials suggest no progress has been made on outstanding points in the latest round of negotiations. Cable has given up its 1.3200 status (vs. high 1.3255) and continues declining in light of pessimistic comments from both the EU and UK Chief Brexit negotiators, with the former nothing that at this stage, a deal seems unlikely and both sides highlight the little progress mate. EUR/GBP has recovered off lows amid the latest Brexit headlines, with the cross initially dipping below the Aug 13th low ~0.8948 before rebounding to session high at 0.8980. DXY - Propped up by the post-PMI Euro - the index is back around 93.000 from an overnight base of 92.570 , with the highs from Wednesday (93.059) and Monday (93.124) the next points of resistance ahead of yesterday's peak at 93.248. Looking ahead to today, the calendar remains light with US Markit PMIs and Existing Home Sales the only scheduled events. JPY - USD/JPY had been ebbing overnight in light of the weaker Dollar during APAC hours, but the JPY holds onto gains in early EU hours despite the Dollar rebound as PMI-related haven flows keeps the Japanese currency buoyed. USD/JPY dipped below 105.50 from 105.80 at best ahead of the weekly base at 105.104. Note: USD/JPY sees around USD 550mln in options rolling off at 105.00 at the NY cut. AUD, CAD, NZD - All narrowly softer in what is a Dollar story. AUD/USD as dipped back below 0.7200 (vs. high 0.7215), whilst Westpac raised its year-end forecast to 0.7500 from 0.7200 as their case of a momentum stall is still not convincing. NZD/USD remains contained within a tight current range of 0.6525-0.6550, with overnight comments from the RBNZ Chief economy noting that the Central Bank has scope to act aggressively if needed. Similarly, the revival of the Dollar and declines in the crude complex sees the Loonie yield, with USD/CAD testing resistance at 1.3200 (vs. low 1.3159) ahead of Canadian Retail Sales, with today's option expiries seeing USD 505mln at 1.3225 alongside a sizeable USD 1.7bln between 1.3250-60. EM - Mixed trade across EMs but the Lira stands out as the outperformer after the CBRT lifted the TRY interest rate on swap transactions from 8.25% to 9.75% yesterday to match the lending rate. Furthermore, the Turkish President is expected to announce 'good news' today in regard to an energy discover in the black sea, most likely natural gas. USD/TRY has trades sub-7.2500 from a high of 7.3380. In commodities, WTI and Brent October futures have waned off overnight highs, albeit with the magnitude of price action relatively small thus far. Crude-specific news flow has remained light, but the contracts saw a sentiment-driven leg lower amid the overall down-beat flash PMIs from the EU. Both contracts trade lower by some USD 0.20/bbl apiece, with WTI testing USD 42.50/bbl to the downside (vs. high 42.96./bbl) whilst its Brent counterpart dipped below USD 44.75/bbl from around USD 45/bbl at best, with only the weekly Baker Hughes rig count slated on the calendar. Elsewhere, spot gold and spot silver yield to the post-PMI Dollar strength, with the former losing further ground below USD 1950/oz (vs. high 1956/oz) whilst latter briefly dipped below USD 27.00 from 27.54 at best. In terms of base metals, copper continued to grind lower with the Shanghai inventories again posting another rise in stocks. Dalian iron ore prices fell overnight as the steel-demand-driven rally somewhat fizzled whilst China's iron ore portside stockpile rose to four-month highs. US Event Calendar 9:45am: Markit US Manufacturing PMI, est. 52, prior 50.9 9:45am: Markit US Services PMI, est. 51, prior 50 9:45am: Markit US Composite PMI, prior 50.3 10am: Existing Home Sales, est. 5.41m, prior 4.72m; MoM, est. 14.62%, prior 20.7% DB's Jim Reid concludes the overnight wrap The brief excitement that we got in markets late Wednesday proved to be fairly short-lived in the end with equities at least pretty much back to the status quo again yesterday. Indeed there were more gains for the S&P which nudged up +0.32% with the NASDAQ (+1.06%) once again leading the way and finishing at yet another record high. However, all this came on a foundation of low volumes and pretty thin breadth of gains when you dig below the surface - a theme that's been fairly consistent all week. A stat that stood out yesterday was that just 30% of the S&P 500 actually advanced with the equal weighted index down -0.55%. In fact, while the benchmark S&P 500 is up +0.38% this week the equal weighted index is actually down -1.43%. In fairness markets did open on the back foot after the latest weekly initial jobless claims data came in at a higher-than-expected 1.106m for the week through August 15. That was well above the consensus forecast of 920k, and marks a rebound from the prior week's 971k reading, which was the first time the weekly number had fallen below a million since the pandemic began. Though it's only one week, the +135k increase in claims is the largest weekly jump since late March, and raises fears that the labour market recovery is unlikely to be a smooth one. While continuing claims represented somewhat better news, with a decline to 14.844m in the week through August 8 (vs 15m expected), they still remain at more than twice the peak after the GFC back in 2009, suggesting there's still a long way to go before we get back to any king of normality. Treasury yields were already a couple basis points lower going into that and they held that level into the evening with 10y yields in particular closing -2.9bps lower. The curve also keeps doing its best to unwind some of last week's bear steepening with 2s10s and 5s30s curves both -3.1bps flatter yesterday. Meanwhile the USD had a more choppy session but ultimately ended a shade weaker with the dollar index down -0.10%. It's also down a further -0.16% this morning. On that, it's worth noting that yesterday our FX team took profit on their EURUSD trade having nearly reached their 1.20 target earlier this week. They now see a more balanced outlook approaching September, with positioning becoming stretched, virus statistics becoming worse in Europe, and the Fed signalling a less dovish stance for September. This isn't to say that they're turning bullish on the dollar all of a sudden, but having nearly reached 1.20 the risks are more evenly balanced in comparison to their strong conviction view earlier this year. See their full note here. Looking ahead to today, the highlight will likely be the release of the flash PMIs for August, which will give us one of the first indications of global economic performance into the month. Overnight, we've already had the Australian and Japanese numbers with Japan's manufacturing PMI coming in at 46.6 (vs. 45.2 last month) however the services print fell to 45.0 (vs. 45.4 last month). The decline in the services PMI was more pronounced in Australia given the localized lockdowns as it came in at 48.1 (vs. 58.2 last month) but the manufacturing PMI was relatively stable at 53.9 (vs. 54.0 last month). Later today, we'll hear from Europe and the US, where the consensus is expecting a continued rebound in activity from the lows of the initial lockdowns. Remember though that these are diffusion indices, so they simply ask respondents whether conditions are better or worse than in the previous month, rather than measuring growth itself. As a result they can struggle to capture the extent of any declines or rebounds when the numbers are at extreme levels as they've been recently. This will be important to keep in mind if the current uptick of coronavirus cases persists and causes partial shutdowns of economies in infected areas. Italy reported the most new cases since mid-May yesterday, while weekly cases in the UK have recently risen over 8000 for the first time since early June. However, despite cases rising, German Chancellor Merkel and French President Macron have indicated they oppose nationwide lockdowns, and want the continent to coordinate a strategy for avoiding a further economic slowdown from the virus. In Asia, South Korea's new infection wave has spread nationwide and the country reported additional 324 cases in the past 24 hours. On the positive side, Pfizer and BioNTech said that their vaccine candidate is on track for regulatory review as early as October, assuming clinical success. Meanwhile, the NHK reported that Japan is set to allow foreign residents shut out by virus-related restrictions back into the country from September. Asian markets have followed Wall Street's lead this morning with the Nikkei (+0.43%), Hang Seng (+1.25%), Shanghai Comp (+0.78%) and Kospi (+2.27%) all up. The positive vaccine news mentioned above seems to be aiding sentiment. Futures on the S&P 500 are also up +0.27%. In terms of other data releases, Japan's July CPI came in line with consensus at +0.3% yoy while both core and core-core CPI came in a shade lower than expectations at unchanged and +0.4% yoy respectively. In other overnight news, President Trump said that 'We will give tax credits to companies to bring jobs back to America, and if they don't do it, we will put tariffs on those companies, and they will have to pay us a lot of money,' if he gets re-elected. Back to yesterday, there weren't any major surprises from the release of the ECB minutes. In terms of things to note, they showed that the Governing Council's focus was shifting away from market stabilisation as a focus towards price stability. For example, the number of references to 'financial conditions' fell to 8 in the latest minutes, having been 23 back in June. There was also more time devoted to the weakness in longer-term inflation expectations, with 3 mentions versus 1 in the last minutes. The STOXX 600 closed down -1.07% in Europe yesterday while bond yields on the continent were 1-3bps lower with the exception of BTPs which finished flat. In other news, yesterday we got confirmation that China and the US are to have a call soon to discuss the progress of their trade deal, expected in the 'near term' although no exact date was given. Kudlow confirmed yesterday that Lighthizer 'has said a number of times that he actually is pleased with the progress' on the trade pact. Further evidence therefore of ring-fencing the trade pact in the US-China tit for tat. Staying with US politics, moderate Democrats from swing states are urging Speaker Pelosi and Congressional Republicans to restart stimulus talks that have stalled. However Pelosi also noted that she would not support a 'skinny bill that only dealt with the unemployment benefits without offering funding help to the states that need it. As for the remaining data yesterday, August's Philadelphia Fed business index came in at 17.2 (vs. 20.8 estimated), down from last month's 24.1 reading. This is the second month in a row that the gauge has fallen, though the ISM adjusted index ticked up higher to 54.1 from 53.6. Over in Europe, the German PPI reading for July was up 0.2% from the previous month (vs. 0.1% expected), while down -1.7% YoY. To the day ahead now, and the data highlight is likely to be the aforementioned flash PMIs for August. As well as that, we'll get UK retail sales and public finance data for July, the advance Euro Area consumer confidence reading for June, US existing home sales for July, and Canada's retail sales for June. urn:contentItem:5WRR-PG01-DYDW-71D6-00000-00G7 finance chiefs pour cold water on Facebook's digital coin plans2019-08-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:51ZLexisNexisG7 finance chiefs pour cold water on Facebook's digital coin plansNew Delhi, 2019-08-06 12:47:47

August 06 -- Group of Seven finance chiefs cast a cloud over prospects for Facebook's Libra digital coin on Wednesday, insisting tough regulatory problems would have to be worked out first.
The massive social media company's plan to launch a digital coin has met with a chorus from regulators, central bankers and governments saying it must respect anti-money-laundering rules and ensure the security of transactions and user data.


But there are also deeper concerns that the powers of big tech companies increasingly encroach on areas belonging to governments, like issuing currency.
"The sovereignty of nations cannot be jeopardised," French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire told journalists after chairing the first day of the two-day meeting.
"The overall mood around the table was clearly one of important concerns about the recent Libra announcements, and a shared view that action is needed urgently," he added.
German Finance Minister Olaf Scholz said Facebook's plans do not "seem to be fully thought through", adding that there were also data security questions.
"I am convinced that we must act quickly and that (Libra) cannot go ahead without all legal and regulatory questions being resolved," Scholz told journalists.
France, which chairs the Group of Seven advanced economies this year, has asked European Central Bank executive board member Benoit Coeure to set up a G7 task force to look into crypto-currencies and digital coins like the Libra.
Coeure presented a preliminary report to ministers and central bankers at the meeting, in the quaint chateau town of Chantilly, north of Paris.
Central bankers say that if Facebook wants to take deposits, it needs a banking licence, which would subject it to the strict regulation that goes with operating in that industry.
Some central bankers also say that allowing people to transact anonymously is a non-starter given financial sector regulations that require payments firms to hold basic information about their customers.
JAPAN: GLOBAL CONSENSUS NEEDED
Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda said the G7 task force was likely to evolve over time into something including a broader range of regulators beyond the group, given the huge impact Libra could have on the global economy.
"If the Libra is aspiring to be used globally, countries must seek a globally coordinated response," Kuroda said.
"This is not something that can be discussed among G7 central banks alone."
G7 finance ministers are also concerned about how best to tax big tech companies, with France keen to use its presidency of the two-day meeting to get broad support for ensuring minimum corporate taxation.
G7 governments are concerned that decades-old international tax rules have been pushed to the limit by the emergence of companies like Facebook and Apple, which book profits in low-tax countries regardless of the source of the underlying income.
The issue has become more vexed than ever in recent days as Paris defied U.S. President Donald Trump last week by passing a tax on big digital firms' revenues in France, despite a threat from Trump to launch a probe that could lead to trade tariffs.
Their bilateral dispute aside, France and the United States are in favour of rules ensuring minimum taxation as part of an effort among nearly 130 countries to overhaul international tax rules.
Although a G7 agreement would set the tone for the broader push, an agreement among all of the G7 ministers on a minimum rate or range of rates is likely to prove elusive as Britain and Canada have reservations, a French Finance Ministry source said.
"If we don't agree at the G7 level on the broad principles for taxing digital companies today or tomorrow, then quite frankly it will be complicated to find among 129 countries at the OECD," Le Maire said.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WM3-V3D1-JCBJ-K3V2-00000-00G7 finance chiefs pour cold water on Facebook's digital coin plans.(Banking & Finance)2019-07-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:51ZLexisNexisG7 finance chiefs pour cold water on Facebook's digital coin plans.(Banking & Finance)

By Reuters

Group of Seven finance chiefs cast a cloud over prospects for Facebook's Libra digital coin on Wednesday, insisting tough regulatory problems would have to be worked out first.

The massive social media company's plan to launch a digital coin has met with a chorus from regulators, central bankers and governments saying it must respect anti-money-laundering rules and ensure the security of transactions and user data.

But there are also deeper concerns that the powers of big tech companies increasingly encroach on areas belonging to governments, like issuing currency.

"The sovereignty of nations cannot be jeopardized," French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire told journalists after chairing the first day of the two-day meeting.

"The overall mood around the table was clearly one of important concerns about the recent Libra announcements, and a shared view that action is needed urgently," he added.

German Finance Minister Olaf Scholz said Facebook's plans do not "seem to be fully thought through", adding that there were also data security questions.

"I am convinced that we must act quickly and that (Libra) cannot go ahead without all legal and regulatory questions being resolved," Scholz told journalists.

France, which chairs the Group of Seven advanced economies this year, has asked European Central Bank executive board member Benoit Coeure to set up a G7 task force to look into cryptocurrencies and digital coins like the Libra.

Coeure presented a preliminary report to ministers and central bankers at the meeting, in the quaint chateau town of Chantilly, north of Paris.

Central bankers say that if Facebook wants to take deposits, it needs a banking license, which would subject it to the strict regulation that goes with operating in that industry.

Some central bankers also say that allowing people to transact anonymously is a non-starter given financial sector regulations that require payments firms to hold basic information about their customers.

JAPAN: GLOBAL CONSENSUS NEEDED

Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda said the G7 taskforce was likely to evolve over time into something including a broader range of regulators beyond the group, given the huge impact Libra could have on the global economy.

"If the Libra is aspiring to be used globally, countries must seek a globally coordinated response," Kuroda said.

"This is not something that can be discussed among G7 central banks alone."

G7 finance ministers are also concerned about how best to tax big tech companies, with France keen to use its presidency of the two-day meeting to get broad support for ensuring minimum corporate taxation.

G7 governments are concerned that decades-old international tax rules have been pushed to the limit by the emergence of companies like Facebook and Apple, which book profits in low-tax countries regardless of the source of the underlying income.

The issue has become more vexed than ever in recent days as Paris defied U.S. President Donald Trump last week by passing a tax on big digital firms' revenues in France, despite a threat from Trump to launch a probe that could lead to trade tariffs.

Their bilateral dispute aside, France and the United States are in favor of rules ensuring minimum taxation as part of an effort among nearly 130 countries to overhaul international tax rules.

Although a G7 agreement would set the tone for the broader push, an agreement among all of the G7 ministers on a minimum rate or range of rates is likely to prove elusive as Britain and Canada have reservations, a French Finance Ministry source said.

"If we don't agree at the G7 level on the broad principles for taxing digital companies today or tomorrow, then quite frankly it will be complicated to find among 129 countries at the OECD," Le Maire said.

CAPTION(S):

Representations of virtual currency are displayed in front of the Libra logo in this illustration picture, June 21, 2019. (REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo / MANILA BULLETIN)

urn:contentItem:5WKF-71T1-DYWP-R1C4-00000-00G7 finance ministers look to rein in tech giants at French meeting2019-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:52:51ZLexisNexisBUSINESSG7 finance ministers look to rein in tech giants at French meeting

CHANTILLY, France: G7 finance ministers will have the growing powers of big digital firms in their sights when they meet on Wednesday outside Paris despite divisions about how best to tax them. France wants to use its presidency of the two-day meeting in the picturesque chateau town of Chantilly north of Paris to get broad support for ensuring minimum corporate taxation. G7 governments are concerned that decades-old international tax rules have been pushed to the limit by the emergence of Facebook and Apple, which book profits in low-tax countries regardless of the source of the underlying income.

The issue has become more vexed than ever in recent days as Paris defied U.S. President Donald Trump last week by passing a tax on big digital firms' revenues in France despite a threat from him to launch a probe that could lead to trade tariffs. "France is a sovereign nation and will continue of course to decide as a sovereign nation on all taxation issues," French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire said at a conference at the French central bank on the eve of the G7 meeting. "So let's work during the G7... on that key question of digital taxation because this is for us the best way to fix this issue," Le Maire added. Their bilateral dispute aside, France and the United States are in favour of rules ensuring minimum taxation as part of an effort among 139 countries to overhaul international tax rules. Although a G7 agreement would set the tone for the broader push, an agreement among all of the G7 ministers on a minimum rate or range of rates is likely to prove elusive as Britain and Canada have reservations, a French Finance Ministry source said on Friday. Common ground should be found more easily among ministers and central bankers present at the meeting on the issue of digital currencies and coins. Facebook's recent announcement of plans to launch a digital coin has met with a chorus from regulators, central bankers and governments insisting it must respect anti-money-laundering rules and ensure the security of transactions and user data. But there are also deeper concerns that the growing powers of big tech companies increasingly encroach on areas belonging to governments, like issuing currency. "These digital giants are turning into private states - states over which citizens have no control and where democracy has no place," Le Maire said. "We cannot let companies, which are serving private interests, gather all the attributes of sovereign states. We must act," he added. Off the official agenda, ministers are also due to consult on possible successors to replace Christine Lagarde at the head of the International Monetary Fund. U.S. Secretary of the Treasury Steven Mnuchin and some European ministers are due to meet with Bank of England Governor Mark Carney, who has been mooted as a possible candidate for the IMF job. (Additional reporting by Myriam Rivet; Editing by Dan Grebler) - Reuters
